TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today because he is in Hobart attending a funeral. Any questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Tate in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the 19 per cent decline in automotive exports in 1988 as reported in the recent report of the Automotive Industry Authority on the state of the industry and also to the slowdown evident in growth of exports of manufactured goods generally since the June quarter last year. I also refer the Minister to the results of the Confederation of Australian Industry-Westpac survey of industrial trends for the March quarter of 1989 which reported a fall in export deliveries to their lowest level in three years. Is he concerned about this apparent stagnation in exports of manufactured goods and to what does he attribute the slowdown?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I recall the figures, the increase in manufacturing exports reached its height in 1987 and there was some decline in 1988 which is reflected in the figures to which Senator Chaney refers. There are a variety of reasons for that decline in performance in the increase in the rate of exports-which is what the decline is. It is a decline, as I recall it, from about a 30 per cent increase in the rate of exports in 1986-87 to some 8 per cent last year. For some industries the value of the dollar during 1988 affected their export performance. For other industries, particularly small firms, we have found as a matter of experience that they seem to have a capacity to increase their exports to the $3m to $5m level. This fact has turned up in the review of the export market development grants scheme being conducted by Professor Hughes. When they reach that level they run out of capacity to increase their exports further. That is why current investment levels are very much welcomed by this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is more specifically directed towards the motor vehicle industry. In the second half of 1988, there was an unanticipated surge in domestic demand which led the industry to being quite unable to satisfy the domestic market and a considerable amount of resources was diverted into satisfying domestic demand rather than into export activity. I consider that not to be a long term decline and one which will be rectified within the next six months or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government received indications that the opposition of vested interests to key aspects of its micro-economic reform program, in particular the deregulation of wheat marketing, is jeopardising public support for these reform initiatives? Is the Government contemplating any changes to its micro-economic reform program as a consequence of these pressures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe there are any significant indications that vested interests are having an effect in generating public opposition to the Government's micro-economic reform agenda. In support of that, only this morning I was given a copy of a short letter which I would like to read out to the Senate. It is addressed to the Federal Parliamentary National Party from the National Party of New South Wales and carries today's date.
—Where did you get that from?
—Senator McKiernan, I am not going to compromise my National Party source by naming who leaked this letter to me. The letter states:

ANSWER.PARA: In your deliberations this morning please take into consideration my sincere conviction that a change in leadership now would have catastrophic short term consequences.
I am aware of the incidence of chronic criticism of Ian Sinclair amongst our financial members and particularly where the influence of agro-politics are felt.

Our public opinion surveys contradict the suggestion that this is indicative of his standing in the wider community and certainly does not identify our leadership as an impediment to an election success.
There can be no doubt a change in leadership in our Party at this time will give Labor their long awaited window-of-opportunity to go to the people on the basis of the disunity of the Opposition.
The Liberal Party's suicidal tendencies are no excuse for us to abandon traditions and values that have sustained this Party throughout its history.

It is signed by Douglas Moppett, State Chairman of the National Party of Australia. I table the letter, Mr President. It seems that not everybody-in the extra-parliamentary National Party anyway-was calm and collected as its new leader would have us believe. But I do believe, however, that even though there is no meaningful resistance to the Government's reform program in this area that Mr Sinclair's role in supporting or expediting a coalition policy in support of the Government policy was certainly the issue which brought him down in the National Party. I think it is a great pity that the best thing that Mr Sinclair has ever done in Parliament-indeed some people will probably go beyond that and say that it is the only good thing he has ever done in his 25 years in Parliament-brought him down as Leader of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to the report last week of the Automotive Industry Authority and his own assessment that if he had been doing an examination and had presented his parents with such a report they would have been less than satisfied. In view of that comment, and the more critical appraisal of the independent commentators about the progress of his motor vehicle plan, I ask him: What are the factors which would give him any confidence that the 1992 report will be more satisfactory from the point of view of Australians who are paying relatively more now for their cars than when the Button plan started? What action, if any, is the Government planning to try to get the car plan back on track?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the difficulties about the car plan is that it has never been understood in the Opposition. Over the years I have had a series of questions about it, some suggesting that it is too interventionist and some, by implication, suggesting that it is not interventionist enough. The car plan is providing a framework for structural adjustment of the motor vehicle industry which it never had before under a series of Liberal governments. When a crisis emerged a firm went bad, sacked a few thousand workers, and off they went. Firm after firm disappeared from this country, having had a go at the market. It was a totally unstructured industry. That has not happened in the years of the car plan.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator MacGibbon may interject `Ha, ha!' but that has not happened in the years of the car plan. There have been no closures of major firms. Instead there have been mergers and a variety of things of that kind.
—But you pay $35,000 for a Falcon.

—It is very important to understand the level of intervention which is involved in the car plan. It provides a structure. We are not about intervening in the internal affairs of firms and telling them what people they should employ, what technology they should employ, what quality standards they should achieve and those sorts of things. Under the car plan those issues are left to the market. The market increasingly becomes more open as tariffs come down in the context of the car plan.

ANSWER.PARA: So I said I was less than satisfied. What was I less than satisfied about? Two particular issues. The first one is price, which Senator Lewis raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the prices that must be paid for--
—Senator Lewis should stop his mumbling. He asked the question and I will give him an answer.
—But you are not answering the question that I asked.
—If it is unpalatable to Senator Lewis he should just shut up and give a little more time and I will answer it for him.
—Order!

—Senator Lewis understands what I am talking about, including my recent invitation to him. The two issues about which I expressed concern were the prices of motor vehicles and the question of quality. I must say that governments cannot make firms adopt quality standards which we would all like. That is the business of firms in the marketplace. We can exhort firms to do better. We can try to improve labour relations and structural adjustment within the work force. We can try to improve the conditions under which people work. We can try to reduce labour turnover. The Government is doing that in terms of labour market programs which I hope will yield results.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of prices let me say that the report which Senator Lewis referred to drew attention to the fact that for the fourth successive quarter the rate of price increase for both locally produced and imported passenger motor vehicles has been below the consumer price index, that is, four quarters of an improving trend. Certainly car prices are higher than they were when the car plan was introduced. The major reason for that is the devaluation of the Australian dollar. Firms embarked on some practices which from the national point of view I would not approve of in terms of following imported prices up. But the trend is now in the right direction.

Senator Lewis asked me what confidence do I have that we will not get the same sort of report in 1992. It is a measure of the integrity of the car plan that it is an authority appointed under the car plan that has been the most stringent critic of the industry in respect of these matters and has been quite frank in its assessment of what has taken place.

In so far as confidence in the 1992 report is concerned, all I can say is what I have said from the beginning of the car plan. If the industry does not get these issues right they will not be here in 1992 under this Government because we will not shift from what we have said about the car plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will not be here either.

—Senator Bishop says that we will not be here either. Senator Bishop will be here. I saw on the front of a magazine a week or two ago Senator Bishop in her football gear kicking Senator Puplick downstairs. Senator Chaney is next cab off the rank, I am told. He is just getting out in time. Deft old Fred is just getting out in time. We will be here, Senator Bishop, so do not worry about that. We will not back off on this issue I am talking about. Every experience of Liberal governments shows that they back off when the going gets a bit tough, just like the Liberal Party did on wheat regulation.
—You are the ones to back off.
—Yes, you did. That is why Senator Boswell is looking so pained and interjecting today. The answer to Senator Lewis's question is simply that I have confidence but there is a lot of work to do.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the galleries of a large number of distinguished former senators and members. All are members of the recently formed Association of Former Members of the Parliament of Australia, which is conducting its second meeting in Parliament House today, the first anniversary of the opening of this building. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome all of you on your return to Parliament House. I think that all of us down here probably have a vested interest in wishing your association a long and prosperous future.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The proposed legislation to deregulate the domestic wheat market has met with some opposition, not only amongst growers but also amongst politicians. Some have argued against deregulation on the grounds of its deleterious effect on organic growers of wheat. Can the Minister tell us the effect of the proposed legislation on organic growers of wheat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of comments have been made about wheat deregulation on the basis of protecting the interests of organic wheat growers. In the main, the people making those comments have been the Australian Democrats. I think it is right to record that the wheat deregulation proposals that the Government will bring before this chamber shortly will advantage organic wheat growers. The present arrangements inhibit the growers of organic wheat and, indeed, impose on them a surcharge that they could well do without and do not need in the present circumstances. There is a very small amount of organic wheat grown in Australia-according to the Wheat Board, about 1,000 tonnes of it is harvested annually-but there is a strong indication that there is a black market in organic wheat, which indicates, so to speak, that growers vote with their sheaves by taking their wheat and selling it directly on the black market in the most unregulated way possible. I do not condone the black market proceedings-of course, I want to see these growers operate through the Australian Wheat Board while those arrangements remain. Nonetheless, the fact that a large number of them do work a black market is indicative of the fact that they perceive that their best interests lie in that direction.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment the problem is that normal grain storage and transport usually involves spraying the grain with insecticides to protect it. Organic wheat growers do not store their grain; under a special provision of the Wheat Board, they sell directly to the millers. Nonetheless, they have to transact their arrangements through the Australian Wheat Board and have those arrangements sanctioned by the Board, which imposes costs on them for that purpose. They sell direct; they arrange their transport and their storage directly as well. Those services that the Australian Wheat Board provides-in their particular case, they are non-services-cost about $10 per tonne in 1987-88, and in some States bulk handling charges are about $5 a tonne. From those points of view there is actually self-interest in growers of organic wheat supporting the amendments, and not taking the view that some Democrat critics put forward-that the amendments are proposed in some funny way and that, somehow or other, they act against the interests of organic wheat growers. That is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is put in the context of Vice-President Quayle's timely warning to the Australian Government that protectionism is still immensely appealing to members of the United States Congress. Given the past tendency of the United States Administration and Congress to seek bilateral deals with countries such as Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore, with which the United States is running a bilateral trade deficit, and given the dangers that this poses for Australia's own access to these important and growing Asian Pacific markets, what specific and additional steps does the Government intend to take to ensure that the reciprocal provisions of the United States Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act do not displace Australia's exports to those countries? Second, given the Minister's commitment last week to raise with the Prime Minister my suggestion of an all-party delegation to the United States to discuss trade issues, does the Minister agree that the use by the United States of section 301 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act is a further important issue that should be raised with the Administration and Congress?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, on the subject of section 301-that is, the bilateral trade remedy provision which is designed to remove so-called unjustifiable or unreasonable foreign trade practices which are identified as such and targeted by the US-a recent report, the US annual national trade estimates report, derived some publicity when it was released a couple of weeks ago. It contains some criticism of Australia's tariff rates as being allegedly too high by a reference to the standards applied for the application of that particular provision. However, it is our belief that not only does Australia not deserve to be targeted under the provisions of the trade Bill to which Senator Macklin referred, but it is unlikely to be so targeted. Certainly, it has not been identified as a priority country because of the pervasiveness of its unfair trade practices, which is the description the US has given to countries like Japan, Korea, India, Brazil and Taiwan. I do not genuinely believe that there is much prospect of this weaponry being deployed against Australia. Of course, if that is to be guaranteed, it will take a continued and persistent lobbying effort by Australia in the United States of the kind we have been visibly engaged in now for a long period, in the context not only of these provisions, but also of export enhancement program provisions and other dimensions of the US farm and trade legislation with which we are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: There is not much I can add at this stage to what I said last week in response to Senator Macklin on the subject of how that can best be done. I have certainly given consideration, as I said I would, to the question of the possible parliamentary delegation to target the congressional leadership, or congressional players, on this issue. Obviously, further opportunities will be taken with high-level visits to the United States coming up later in the year to pursue the issue with the administration. Equally, in the context of the Uruguay Round on multilateral trade negotiations, we will take every available opportunity both to defend our own trading practices and to seek to remove barriers elsewhere.

That leads me to note, in the context of Australia's trade policy and our very active commitment to multilateral trade liberalisation, that I doubt very much if any similarly coherent approach could be expected under the new leadership of the Liberal Party. Mr Peacock's first substantive foray into policy issues this morning occurred in the context of his press conference when he embarked upon an analysis of the deficiencies in our present trade policy. I paraphrase when I say that he said we need to take a broader perspective to see Australia playing an objective role in the region:

. . . to be taking beyond the mere talk of OECD type Secretariat for interchange of views. I would be looking for a trading arrangement as such in circumstances where Britain enters into the whole European, united Europe, if you like, United States/Europe after 1992 to misuse the term; where the Soviet Union herself is freeing up, where the Peoples Republic of China has ten years of that, and where the North American free trade arrangement has taken place. Trade is the lifeblood of this country and arrangements in the region have to be pursued with far greater vigour than they have.

That is totally incoherent, totally half-baked, or both. I am inclined to focus in particular on the half-baked dimensions in so far as what is clearly implied, from my reading of that tortured prose, is a commitment by Mr Peacock to a regional trading bloc arrangement to counter what he appears to be identifying as the problems of Europe post-1992 and North America. One thing is absolutely clear, not only to the rest of the world but also to the region and to any economic commentator who even begins to understand these issues: it is that not only is a regional trading bloc not a credible proposition, because of its incapacity ever to be delivered, given the diversity of the economies within this region and the incapability accordingly of drawing a ring around them in the way that one can credibly with Europe or North America; it is also a proposition that is manifestly at odds with Australia's interest as a trading nation in getting multilateral trade liberalisation applying around the world. If this is a signal of what is to come from the new leadership of the Liberal Party and if it is an example of the total incoherence of the approach of the new leadership to any important policy issue that this country has to confront-and I am sure it is-we on this side of the Parliament can rest easily, reinforced in the confidence that we have always had that we will be here for a very long time indeed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIBERAL PARTY: COST OF CHANGE IN LEADERSHIP

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services outline to the Senate the costs involved in the changes of leadership that occurred this morning in the Liberal and National parties? Will the Department of Administrative Services need to seek supplementary funding to cover those costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —In no way does the Government begrudge those costs. Every time we change a Minister, similar costs occur. There will be a variety of costs to be met by the Department of Administrative Services. The first cost will be incurred in simply moving offices. For instance, the former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, will have to be moved from the eighth or ninth floor in Phillip Street to the top floor or he may, of course, choose to move back to his electorate-in which case the cost would be much higher. Obviously, we will have to upgrade the Melbourne office of the new Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, to the status that the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia would require. The former Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, will have to move out of his Phillip Street office. He may choose to move upstairs or back to Tamworth where, in 1984, after 21 years, he finally established an electorate office. In any event, moving the new Leader of the National Party, Mr Blunt, into his office will not cost much. However, it may be difficult to get the key and the car park pass back. Apart from that, no great costs will be involved.

ANSWER.PARA: The biggest costs will probably be in termination payments. I do not think anyone treats this subject with much humour. Some 18 staff were attached to former leader Howard, each of whom is entitled to termination expenses. As well, as a former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard will be entitled to an assistant private secretary. That will be no bother for the Government because the then former Leader of the Opposition and now Leader of the Opposition had that entitlement and will forfeit it. In actual fact, we will break even on those costs. We never recognised Mr Sinclair as a leader, in spite of six years of intense lobbying by him to get all of the rights to which he thought he was entitled. In 1975 he managed to deprive the Labor Party of those rights. Over all of those years he applied for those extra entitlements but we refused his requests, so the cost of his termination is nowhere near as expensive as it would have been had we been soft during those years. We now have the strange situation of not having a Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in the House of Representatives-yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.

—Very well. In those circumstances I would think that Mr Blunt is probably entitled to what the new Leader of the Opposition had before he replaced the former Leader of the Opposition today, and should be entitled to pick up what we denied Mr Sinclair. I have noted that Senator Chaney has always been a frugal Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, so his costs will not increase. We all know him, and there is no way he will double-dip his entitlement as Opposition Leader in the Senate and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party. So there will be no increased costs there.

ANSWER.PARA: The final cost concerns letterheads. Unfortunately, with a change of leadership we have to change a variety of letterheads. We will definitely be keeping Mr Howard's letterhead. We will not make the same mistake twice. He might be back in a few weeks, a few months or following the next election. Unfortunately we did not keep the letterhead for Mr Peacock. In a statement made immediately after the election of Mr Howard Mr Peacock, when asked, `Would you have not abandoned your ambitions?', said:
Well, I haven't. Maybe a decade or so hence.

. . . may take me another twenty years mightn't it. But the important point is that John Howard has to know that he can go to the next election and maybe beyond with the full support of his Parliamentary team.

Four pages later Senator Chaney endorsed that principle but, unfortunately, the late arrival of Senator Austin Lewis cut off the rest of his words for posterity. I would love to know what they were to be. Unfortunately, we have missed the boat with Mr Peacock's letterhead. We will not be required to supply very much more equipment as a result of today's events. However, I suggest that we send a polygraph to Mr Peacock's office so that when Senator Chaney goes there and professes his loyalty to the leadership he can at least be tested on the matter. One has to acknowledge that the costs involved in these matters are just part of political life. We will not be seeking additional appropriations. It would also be churlish not to congratulate Senator Chaney on his promotion to Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party but I remind him of the immortal words of Sir Winston Churchill that it does not take much courage to rat, but it takes a lot of courage to re-rat.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may bring the Senate back to serious matters, I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface it by referring to the mounting concern among Australians about the sharply rising level of our foreign debt and also the growing concern about the large and rising level of foreign ownership of Australian assets including, but not only, land. I ask the Minister: Firstly, is it a fact that both these developments result from the need to finance the continuing massive deficits on the balance of payments which, for six years now, Australia has incurred under this Government's policies? Secondly, is it also a fact that the magnitude of our foreign debt and indeed the Australian dollar cost of paying interest on it will be increased even further by any fall which there may be in the value of the Australian dollar? Lastly, what is the Government doing even to halt, let alone reverse, the growth in the level of our debts to foreigners and/or the process whereby Australian land and other assets are continuing to fall into the hands of foreigners, or does the Government simply not care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike Senator Stone, I regard leadership changes in the Opposition as quite serious matters. I do not think they are frivolous at all, although I suppose anybody who has been watching the attempt by the Opposition to turn such matters into a comedy over the last few years could be forgiven for believing so. The foreign debt, by definition, is the accumulated current account deficits, net of any current account surplus-and they have not happened too often in Australia's history. Off the top of my head I can think of only one year when we had a current account surplus, but there may have been others.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Stone knows very well, and as anybody else who bothers to listen to what I say in Question Time or other public fora will know, I certainly regard the current account deficit as a serious matter. Senator Stone, however, seeks to put all the blame clearly on the present Government. The root causes of it, as Senator Stone knows very well, go back at least several decades to when the structural inefficiency of the Australian economy was being concreted by John McEwen and Senator Stone's other National Party predecessors with, of course, the supine acceptance of the majority Liberal Party in coalition governments of the day.

In 1982-83, the then Government managed to run up a current account deficit in excess of 4 per cent of gross domestic product in the middle of the deepest depression that we had seen for 50 years. It is clearly correct also that the current account deficit in this year will also be greater than 4 per cent of gross domestic product-and it is the proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) which is the more valid measure of a debt problem over a period of time, of course, than the absolute amount of the debt. The 4 per cent plus of GDP which this year's current account deficit will equal is incurred at a time of the biggest investment boom that we have ever recorded, and, while that is not the only factor, it is very clearly the major factor in increasing the current account deficit of the Budget forecast levels. It is relatively easy to incur a fairly big current account deficit when one is having an investment boom-the biggest investment boom on record, I believe-but it is pretty difficult to incur a current account deficit of that size when one is having the biggest recession for 50 years. But that is what the previous Government managed to achieve.

In regard to foreign ownership of land, I am surprised that Senator Stone has moved so far from, I would say, his intellectual integrity and rigour of his Treasury days. That statement does not mean that I have often agreed with a lot of the conclusions that he reached, because he was very dogmatic and had a very certain view of the world. But I am amazed and disappointed that he has moved so far from his attitude of rigour as Secretary to the Treasury towards the cheap populism of the National Party of Australia that he now represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether he will not agree that his initial response to my question was in error when he said that the level of net foreign debt represented the accumulation of balance of payments deficits and that, presumably, what he meant to say was that the net level of foreign debt plus the net level of foreign ownership represented the accumulation of balance of payments deficits. Having got that point established-and I hope the Minister will agree with the correction-could we also get it clear whether the Minister agrees that, if he is in fact comparing the policies of the present Government with those of its predecessor, we are looking at a situation in which foreign debt has risen from something like $22 billion when this Government took office to $95 billion at the end of last December? I am talking in net terms, of course. If he wants to have those figures in terms of percentages of GDP, to which I think he also referred, will he also agree that the figures also represent a rise from something like 10 per cent of GDP to something more than 30 per cent of GDP? Finally, will the Minister respond to the final part of my question, which was: What is the Government doing to stop the headlong growth in both the rate of our foreign debt and the rate of growth of foreign ownership of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to get engaged in pedantry about jargon, but I think Senator Stone quoted me as allegedly having said that the foreign debt, by definition, was the accumulated balance of payments deficits. But I do not think I said that. I may have done. If I said `balance of payments deficits' I was certainly wrong, because, the balance of payments, as one of the honourable senator's former deputy secretaries once pointed out to Senator Messner at a Senate Estimates committee hearing, is always, by definition, in balance. If I did say `balance of payments' I should have said `the accumulated current account deficits'.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that Senator Stone then went on to refer to accumulated balance of payments deficits, or current account deficits-I am not sure which one it was that he used-plus foreign ownership. That is not counted in foreign debt. Equity in Australia owned by foreigners is not counted as part of our foreign debt. The honourable senator knows that very well. But Senator Stone did point, of course, to another important variable which has emerged in the last few years, and that is that the amount of equity investment in other countries undertaken by Australians and Australian companies has grown enormously. I have forgotten the precise figures but particularly around 1986-87 there was a huge increase in the ownership of foreign assets by Australians. Had that not taken place one would have expected the current account deficit, and therefore what is recorded as Australia's debt, to have reduced commensurately. Having said all that, I do not pretend, and I never have pretended, that I do not see our foreign debt and our continuing current account deficit as very serious problems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the preamble to Senator Sanders's question, I am not aware of confusion in the community over the Government's position on pulp mills. —You said you rejected their application.

—I missed out on Senator Puplick's interjection. All I can say, whatever it was, is that I am delighted with the decision the Government made in respect of Wesley Vale. It was, of course, correct. We were not prepared to pay the sorts of environmental prices that Senator Puplick and his former leader, Mr Howard, were prepared to pay. We have some respect for Bass Strait. The first question referred to the difference between a kraft mill and a thermo-mechanical pulping mill and whether I am aware of it. Yes, I am aware of the difference and I am sure that the Government is aware of the difference as well. The second question referred to whether we were aware of the fact that a kraft mill which uses no chlorine bleach is still environmentally hazardous. Yes, I am aware of that too. I try to keep up a little bit with these processes. We have a team of Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) scientists, departmental officials and representatives from industry which is now looking at pulp mill processes in Scandinavia. The team will probably go on to Canada as well. We want it to look at the most environmentally acceptable processes so that we can develop the toughest standards and guidelines in the world. ANSWER.PARA: As the Prime Minister announced on the weekend, after the Tasmanian election he and the new Tasmanian Premier, Mr Field, will jointly undertake with their officials a study to look at the feasibility of a new Tasmanian mill which might produce unbleached paper products. The fourth question referred to the technique used by Holmen, one of Sweden's major producers. The CSIRO team, to which I have already referred, will, I hope, investigate all processes. We are aware that there are alternatives to the kraft process. There are quite a number of alternatives, not just the one. It is my hope that when that team comes back we will get a report on all of them, certainly, at least, on all of those which at the moment are able to be used commercially.

It is worth noting that there is a trial process in West Germany at the moment which involves non-chlorine bleaching as well. I hope that we might get some report on that. In looking at alternatives to the chlorine bleaching process, we are aware of the need and the desire that so many Australians have for creating a market for unbleached or recycled paper. TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Although this question seems to be a largely environmental related question, on the advice of staffers in Senator Richardson's office I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I hope that he can give me an answer. Can the Minister tell the Senate who represented Australia at the recent conference in Helsinki, Finland, where, as reported in the Australian on 4 May, 80 countries pledged support for a proposal to eliminate chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) by the year 2000? What position did Australia put at Helsinki in regard to Norway's proposal for industrialised nations to contribute 0.1 per cent of their gross national product (GNP) to a fund for assisting Third World countries to meet the CFC phase-out target? Given Australia's ozone protection legislation which falls far short of phasing out CFCs by the year 2000, will Australia be participating in a second conference planned for London next year and, if so, what positions will Australia be taking with regard, firstly, to the elimination of CFCs and, secondly, to assistance to the Third World countries in achieving this aim? Finally, in view of the urgency of the situation, as reflected at Helsinki, does the Government intend to revise the Ozone Protection Bill to bring it into line with international commitments to phase out the production and use of CFCs by the year 2000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the reason Senator Richardson gave this question the flick is that it is such a boring answer which I am now obliged to respond with. Australia was represented at a meeting in Helsinki from 2 to 5 May of parties to the Montreal Protocol on the protection of the ozone layer. The Australian delegation comprised Mr J. A. Whitelaw, Assistant Secretary of the Environmental Quality Branch of the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and Mr Patrick Cole, First Secretary of the Australian Embassy in Stockholm.

ANSWER.PARA: Early in the proceedings Norway proposed to commit 0.1 per cent of its GNP per year toward an international climate fund to provide incentives for developing countries to meet the strength and requirements of the Montreal Protocol. That is, of course, an extraordinary large commitment, and I note that, in the case of Australia, this sort of percentage would be just under one-third of our total annual overseas development assistance.

No other delegation made specific monetary commitments, and a number underlined the desirability of, first, closely examining, and perhaps strengthening, existing mechanisms for providing financial and technical assistance to developing countries. Australia intervened in the debate to indicate that we supported the principle of assisting developing countries in this area. We believed that assistance should stress the development of appropriate new technologies, and we prefer an open-ended review of the suitability of existing mechanisms for channelling the resources involved to relevant countries.

Australia will be represented at the second conference on the ozone layer, which will be held in London in 1990. It is too early to say what Australia's position on the elimination of CFCs will be at that meeting. As Senator Vallentine acknowledged, this matter does lie principally within the portfolio of Senator Richardson, but I understand that a working group of the Australian Environment Council is examining the potential phase-out dates for a range of CFCs which, I am advised, are expected to go significantly further than the requirements of the Montreal protocol and of existing Australian legislation.

—I was asked whether I had anything to add to the letter. Of course, it blows right out of the water the nonsense that Mr Cameron, amongst others, has been peddling for the last six or eight months. I believe that, as a result of this letter and other things, at least Mr Cameron and Senator Walters, and some of the other TSMs who have been cheer-chasing among their League of Rights squad on this issue for the last six or eight months, ought to apologise to the Statistician. Also, in view of the vast amount of misrepresentation, obfuscation, deception and fatuous rhetoric which this issue has generated, I think the letter that the Statistician wrote to Estimates Committee C ought also to be tabled. —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a Bill recently introduced into the Victorian Parliament by the Cain Government called the Prices Bill, which seeks to control price increases for goods sold in Victorian shops? Does the Minister support this Prices Bill and the attempts by the Victorian Government to seek an almost blanket control over prices in Victoria? What effects will this piece of legislation have on the Victorian economy and the wider Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of the Bill, which do not go as far as Senator Messner contends-that the Bill would bring in a regime of blanket price control in Victoria. The Federal Government's approach to prices has been very much one of freeing up the marketplace to ensure that competition has a very healthy and strong effect in terms of reduction of prices. In our aims to achieve that, we have recognised that in particular States at particular times there has been a need for further intervention. In fact, it is recognised that a number of States in Australia have an interventionist approach to prices. For our part, we have worked on a Federal level to coordinate the Government's approach in Australia to ensure, first, that each government knows what the other is doing and, secondly, that there can be an overall coordination of direction of pricing policy.

ANSWER.PARA: To that effect, together with the Prices Surveillance Authority, I have had a number of discussions over the last 12 months with State officials in order to ensure greater coordination of prices policy. It should also be recognised that not only is Victoria moving to intervene in terms of the pricing structures of some particular commodities and other services, but also the Opposition in Tasmania has for some time now been advocating a similar approach. It is one which, from all reports I have seen from Tasmania, has received a great degree of support from sectors of the community in that State. Fran Bladel, the shadow spokesperson in Tasmania, has been pursuing very strongly a policy which allows for some State government control in essential areas.

The Federal Government has been trying to coordinate its approach, which has been to rely much more on the competitive forces in the marketplace, to ensure that prices reach an acceptable level. However, we also have in place the Prices Surveillance Authority, an institution which has a role to play in ensuring that, when prices are increased, those increases are based on the premise of what can be generally classified as justifiable price increases. That authority has a very healthy role to play in terms of keeping a check on prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the answers to four questions asked of me in recent days by honourable senators. The legislation applies not only to service personnel, but to the total Australian community. The Public Eye newspaper acknowledged its error in stating that six months was the limit before payment of benefits ceased. Its retraction on 30 March 1989 gave the correct period of three years. Overseas postings for members of the Australian Defence Force rarely exceed three years in duration. I remind honourable senators that service personnel serving overseas and their families already receive considerable cost of living allowances and rental subsidies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell has asked a number of questions concerning phosphate mining operations in Christmas Island. I have examined the issues raised by Senator Boswell and can assure honourable senators that none of the statements I have made are inaccurate in so far as they go. When discussing the Elders Resources Ltd royalty payment during last Friday's debate on the Arts, Territories and Environment Legislation Amendment Bill and in referring to a comparison of percentages I included, on the advice of my Department, the $1 per tonne to be used for rehabilitation, which gave a $2.70 per tonne total royalty for the Elders offer. I am informed by my Department that this is the figure as it now stands as a result of the further negotiations envisaged in the liquidator's recommendations to the then Minister. It is not relevant, however, in the context of the liquidator's assessment and should not have been used in commenting on the original proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: I also quoted from the liquidator's report the fact that the Booth proposal offered slightly higher royalty payments. I have since spoken to the liquidator and to departmental officers. The liquidator has taken me through the calculations on which he based his finding that Mr Booth offered a slightly higher royalty payment. I understand how he says he reached that conclusion. I also said on Friday that the liquidator noted in his conclusions that the Elders proposal maximises the return to the Commonwealth both through net payments for assets and for royalties. In making that statement I was referring to the overall assessment made by the liquidator. I went on to refer to the slight difference in favour of the Booth proposal, and quoted from the liquidator's report.

The liquidator concluded that Elders was superior both to Century Metals and Mining and Booth in respect of financial resources, production and technical expertise, mainland support bases, research and development, and quality of submission. In effect he concluded that Elders was a major Australian public resources company and it had the expertise and back-up to deliver on its tender. That conclusion was consistent with the advice of the Attorney-General's Department as to the liquidator's responsibilities. In short, the liquidator identified those factors as being sufficient to offset what, in his opinion, was a slight difference in royalty payments. On this basis the then Minister had no reason not to accept the recommendations of the liquidator and I see no reason to change the current course of action as it has maximised the opportunity for the Commonwealth to obtain the greatest available return.

In his question on 3 May, Senator Boswell asked whether I was aware that, at current market prices, the Booth proposal could result in the Government's obtaining approximately 30 per cent more in royalties than in Elders' best case and at least 200 per cent more than in Elders' worst case. I must say that I am not really aware of the basis for these figures, but I am aware that the figures provided by Mr Booth in his proposal produced a result only slightly higher than the Elders proposal. I can say that the liquidator has informed me that the figure was closer to 3 per cent than 30 per cent on the basis of the information before him when he did his assessment. However, in an attempt to settle the differences in understanding, I have arranged for Mr Booth to meet my colleague the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the liquidator and departmental officers to discuss the matter in full. Until these discussions are completed, no contracts or leases with Elders will be finalised. I will inform the Senate of the outcome of the discussions and bring anything of substance to the attention of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

I thank the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, for his explanation, but I believe that he has misled the Senate by asserting that the assessor of the Christmas Island mining proposal, Mr Yeomans, recommended a proposal which maximised financial returns to the Commonwealth. This misleading by the senior territories Minister occurred in answer to a recent question on notice, and was compounded by his answer to a question without notice last Wednesday, during the debate in the Senate on Friday, and in answer to a question without notice yesterday. I have continually warned the Minister to watch where he is going, but Mr Yeomans's assessment itself acknowledged that a Perth consortium headed by a Mr J. G. Booth was offering the same net payment and a slightly higher royalty payment than Elders Resources Ltd, the company that he recommended. The Elders proposal was a flat $1.70 per tonne royalty, whereas the Booth consortium offer was a 5 per cent rate based on selling price per tonne shipped. I repeat that at current market prices the Booth proposal could result in the Government obtaining approximately 30 per cent more in royalties than for Elders' best case, and at least 100 per cent more than for Elders' worst case.

On Friday Senator Richardson asserted that Elders' proposal maximised returns to the Commonwealth because it also offered rehabilitation to the value of $1 per product tonne shipped, and that this offset Booth's superiority on royalties. However, Mr Yeomans's assessment did not conclusively compare proposals on the basis of rehabilitation. Furthermore, it acknowledged that he made no expert assessment on the likely cost of rehabilitation. More importantly, the Booth proposal assumed an open-ended responsibility to rehabilitate all mined areas as an integral part of the extraction process where Elders' offer was limited to the value of $1 per product tonne.

Senator Richardson also asserted that Mr Yeomans acted in accordance with the Attorney-General's advice, that he would assess proposals on the basis of the best return to the Commonwealth-Senator Richardson has just admitted that that was not the case-and that he would not be concerned with the viability except in so far as it may effect the potential purchaser's capacity to pay. There was no question of the Booth consortium's capacity to pay. As Mr Yeomans's assessment acknowledged, members of the Booth consortium were experienced in mining and, viewed collectively, companies of substance.

I repeat that this is an extremely serious case of misleading the Parliament. While I certainly acknowledge that Senator Richardson has never deliberately meant to mislead Parliament, I believe that his Department has not informed him properly. The bureaucracy has long been aware of the contentious issues in this matter and I believe has not explained the whole basis of those issues to the Minister. I believe the Minister's Department has snowed him in some areas. To this extent Senator Richardson has been guilty of not exercising sufficient control over his portfolio and his junior Minister, despite my repeated warnings. This matter which I have exposed has obvious implications for the validity of the assessment of Christmas Island's future. Senator Richardson must apologise to the Senate, look at his Department heads and consult with the Opposition in conducting some form of reassessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I only wish that Senator Boswell had taken note of my answer. I went to some length, as a result of three questions asked by Senator Boswell, to get to the bottom of the matter. TALK.START.PARA: —I now turn to a rather detailed question asked of me yesterday by Senator MacGibbon. In fact, there were seven parts to it, which shows how questions are going in the Senate these days. The first part of the question asked: Did a Royal Australian Navy (RAN) Oberon class submarine undergo intermediate docking in Western Australia recently? The answer to that is yes. It was HMAS Oxley, and it was docked between 2 February 1989 and 18 April 1989. The second part was: Were there slipping problems? There were some minor problems, as could be expected when undertaking only the first submarine docking and the second warship docking at this new shiplift. These were also the first ever dockings of major RAN warships to be conducted in Australia using a shiplift. The third part of the question was: Were there difficulties getting the submarine onto the lift, necessitating three attempts instead of one? There were no difficulties getting the submarine into the lift. Two attempts were needed to sue-that is, to make first contact between keel and keel blocks-the submarine in the correct position both longitudinally and laterally. This is not unusual and results from slight movement of the ship or submarine at the moment of first contact under the influences of wind and waves. After docking a problem with the configuration of the docking cradle was observed and it was decided to reposition elements of the cradle necessitating redocking for the intermediate docking.

ANSWER.PARA: The fourth question was: Did the submarine move or slip on its blocks when it was out of the water, thereby causing hull damage? The answer is that the submarine did not move or slip in its blocks. Some minor denting of the external tanks, that is, not involving the pressure hull or watertight integrity, occurred due to discrepancies in the positioning of some bilge blocks on the shiplift platform. The submarine was undocked, the blocks repositioned and the submarine redocked before proceeding with the intermediate docking.

The fifth question was: Were periscopes and other masts damaged by foreign objects and needing repair because customary protection was not afforded them. The answer is that the periscope and one mast were affected by dust and grit blasting operations because the Navy had not taken normal precautions. Subsequently at HMAS Stirling Navy removed the periscope and mast for cleaning particulate contamination from lubricating greaseways. No mechanical damage had been done. The sixth question was: Who paid, the contractor or the taxpayer? The answer is that the cost of the ballast tank repairs was borne by the contractor. The task and the cost of cleaning the periscope and mast were carried out by Navy.

The seventh question asked was: Have Navy personnel been prohibited from discussing this matter? The answer to that is no. The ballast tank damage took the form of deformation of light plating. The damage was minor and the submarine could have operated without it being repaired. The slight chop on the water which made sueing difficult tends to develop in the evenings. Plans are being developed by the Western Australian Government to build a breakwater to protect the shiplift and wet berth from this sort of weather, starting in a few weeks and ending before HMAS Swan is due to undock at the end of her refit.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TRANSPORT TRUST ACCOUNT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Capital Territory has an admirable public transport system, which is actually a rarity in this late twentieth century. In many cities of the earth the public transport system has been allowed to wither away and die and they have become choked with automobiles. Certainly this is the case in my native home of Los Angeles where it is impossible to move. Los Angeles has a situation called `gridlock'. Cars are proliferating at such a rate that it is difficult to move from intersection to intersection. Canberra still has a very fine rapid transit system which will serve us in good stead. As our fossil fuel resources run out people will be forced to come back to public transport. However, there are some difficulties.

There is a general enthusiasm from Canberra residents for the transport system. The drivers are courteous, especially to tourists. Prices are generally moderate, especially discount pre-paid tickets. I point out here that when I was a member of the House of Assembly in Tasmania a former traffic manager for the local metropolitan transport trust came to me with the proposition that it would actually be cheaper to run the buses free; in other words, collect no fares rather than collect them. He made a very good case; that when one collects fares one has to have a whole fare-collecting mechanism. It is also dangerous to the drivers because of the amounts of cash they carry. I will not continue along that line but I point out that there is still an argument for the free bus system. Anyway, the prices are relatively moderate in the Australian Capital Territory transport system.

One thing that might be an improvement to the system is annual pre-paid tickets as well as the monthly pre-paid tickets which are now available. The routes are logical in the Australian Capital Territory but there is a difficulty in that all routes go through Civic, through the radial system. One proposal I might offer would be a perimeter system linking the townships. Perhaps a light rail service, as suggested by many candidates in the Assembly campaign, may be another proposal. Another proposal might be a rationalised ticketing service so that one ticket equals one journey. At present a new ticket is needed for each change of a bus at the Civic interchange. Another proposal is more frequent servicing of large diesel buses. This would ensure that they do not pollute the atmosphere with the black diesel smoke which is such a menace in the downtown centre of Canberra at the moment.

The after-hours services of the bus system are few and far between. This is not unusual for bus services around the world but as we profess to have one of the better bus services in the world it would be good if the services, especially to the outlying communities, could be more frequent. The situation is getting so bad that a teacher at Hall, which is at the northern tip of Canberra, gets a $1.61 daily allowance for driving her car because she works in an `isolated' establishment. Hall is not all that far out of town but the buses are irregular and the last bus leaves Hall at 3.05 p.m. She is, therefore, forced to use a car.

The unfortunate fact is that the Australian Capital Territory, like other communities, is becoming more and more besotted with the automobile. We have the bus system and we also have an area which is admirably suitable for bicycles. I suppose that human beings being what they are, it will take an increase in the price of petrol and the price of automobiles and servicing to force them to do what they should do and that is use our rapid transit systems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The Bill will amend various taxation acts to give effect to matters announced on 12 April by the Treasurer in his economic statement.
The Bill will declare the general rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1989-90 and subsequent financial years.
It will also declare the rate of fringe benefits tax to apply from 1 April 1990.

The Bill will also allow instalments payable under the quarterly provisional tax system to be reduced to take account of the reduction in tax rates.
PERSONAL TAX RATES
I turn now to the personal income tax rate measures contained in the Bill.
The reform of the rate scales will be in two stages.
With effect from 1 July 1989 a five-step scale will apply and this will reduce to a four-step scale from 1 January 1990.
There is to be no change in the tax-free threshold of $5,100.
From 1 July 1989 the existing 24 per cent rate will be reduced to 21 per cent and will apply to income over $5,100 and up to a new threshold level of $17,650.
The 29 per cent rate will continue to apply, but in the altered income range $17,651 to $20,600.

The existing 40 per cent rate will be reduced to 39 per cent and apply to income from $20,601 to $35,000. For income over $35,000 and up to $50,000 the rate of 49 per cent will be reduced to 47 per cent.

Finally, for income over $50,000 the 49 per cent rate will be reduced to 47 per cent from 1 January 1990. To give effect to this decision a composite rate of 48 per cent will apply to that income on assessment for the 1989-90 year of income.
These tax cuts will be reflected in lower pay-as-you-earn deductions from 1 July 1989 and, in the case of income over $50,000, from 1 January 1990.
The changes to the rate scale will also affect non-residents with the rate of 29 per cent applying on income up to $20,600 and above that amount reduced rates will apply as for residents.

Other rates to be reduced include the rate on unearned income of minors which will be 48 per cent for 1989-90 and 47 per cent for all subsequent years, subject to shading-in arrangements for income just over $416.

The cost to revenue of the personal tax cuts and the increases I will outline shortly to dependant rebates is $4,900m in 1989-90 and $5,700m in 1990-91.
FRINGE BENEFITS TAX RATE
The rate of fringe benefits tax will be reduced to 47 per cent for the year of tax commencing on 1 April 1990 and subsequent years.
The cost to revenue is estimated at $55m in 1990-91 and $60m in 1991-92.
DEPENDANT REBATES
Increased levels of concessional rebates for dependants are being made available for 1989-90 and subsequent income years.
As announced by the Treasurer, the dependant spouse rebate will be increased to $1,000, and to $1,200 where there is a dependant child or student.
Similar increases will apply to the rebates for a daughter-housekeeper or a housekeeper.
The level of the sole parent rebate is being increased to $940 and the levels of the concessional rebates for an invalid relative, a parent or a parent-in-law are also being increased.
There will be a flow-on of these increases to the zone rebates of tax for people in isolated areas.
INDEXATION OF CONCESSIONAL REBATES

In addition, the Bill will give effect to the announcement that from 1990-91 the concessional rebates referred to earlier will be indexed annually on the basis of movements in the all groups Consumer Price Index.
QUARTERLY PROVISIONAL TAX

The Bill will permit the Commissioner of Taxation to reduce to an appropriate level the amount of a quarterly provisional tax instalment otherwise payable in circumstances such as these where tax cuts have been announced.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
