WHEAT MARKETING BILL 1989
The purpose of this Bill is to introduce new marketing arrangements for the wheat industry and thereby establish a sound future for one of Australia's most important export earners.

In a speech to the Annual Conference of the Grains Council of Australia last year, I invited the industry to take the opportunity of the need for a new Wheat Marketing Act and the Report of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage Handling and Transport to think seriously about the future structure of the wheat industry and its position in the Australian and world economy.
It is a matter of some regret that the GCA has been unable to articulate a vision for the future of its industry and has adopted a position of non-negotiability on the major issues.
While the GCA has been arguing for the status quo it seems not to understand that this is an industry which has been undergoing continuous and, in some cases, quite major change. For instance:
wheat growing is becoming part of a broader grains industry in which more growers are prepared to make changes in their cropping based on relative prices
the industry has recently weathered extremely unfavourable market conditions caused by heavy export subsidisation by the US and EC
wheat purchasers are becoming more specific about the quality characteristics they seek

the AWB's operations have changed significantly over the last decade. For instance the Board is now a significant offshore borrower. More recently the AWB has provided growers with more flexible delivery options through the introduction of pool cash out arrangements, warehousing and a special stockfeed segregation.
the domestic market has already been partially deregulated with the introduction of permits for feed wheat and continued black market trading.
growers have been getting more experience of alternative methods of selling their grain. Even the GCA has recognised this through its recent establishment of the National Grain Exchange.

The industry has shown that it can respond to the pressures for change. It must continue to have this flexibility. The wheat market is currently very buoyant due to a combination of crop shortages and a rundown in US stocks. However the mechanisms which encourage over-production in some countries remain in place. We are seeking through the GATT Uruguay Round to have these measures wound back, and I am very pleased that during recent negotiations in Geneva progress was achieved in setting out a long and short-term framework for liberalising agricultural trade. However, much remains to be done since Australia cannot compete with the treasuries of the US and EC. We can only respond to difficulties on the world market by ensuring that we not only grow, but also handle and market our grain as efficiently as possible.
This objective cannot be achieved while unnecessary regulation and controls limit the AWB's effectiveness and impose extra costs on growers and users of wheat.

The Bill contains provisions to retain the AWB's export monopoly, but to open up more choice for growers by deregulating the domestic wheat market. In place of the compulsion contained in the current marketing arrangements the Government is introducing a range of measures to extend the AWB's commercial powers and flexibility to ensure that it will be able to compete effectively in a deregulated market. The Bill also gives effect to the Government's concern to minimise its own control over the AWB's operations and to extend the Board's accountability to growers. The AWB will not be weakened as has been claimed, but will be significantly strengthened.

Specifically, and most importantly, the AWB will have clear powers to buy wheat for cash. This will enable it to remain a force in the domestic market, but will also ensure that it has the flexibility to access particular qualities of wheat for export if these are not made available through the pooling system.

Second, while the AWB's principal objective will remain the marketing of wheat, it will have the scope to market other grains and wheat grown in other countries where this assists its wheat marketing effort.

Third, the AWB will still be able to pool returns but it will have flexibility in deciding how to conduct these operations. Under the current Wheat Marketing Act there is a single ASW pool with differentials established for other grades. This leads to inflexibility. Under the new legislation the AWB will be able to establish separate pools for separate grades or time periods. This, together with a wider range of payment options, will provide greater scope for responding to market movements.

I should also point out that the legislation does not make any specific requirements of the AWB regarding its pooling activities and the balance between these and any direct trading in wheat. This will be for the AWB and growers to decide in consultation.

The AWB will also have powers to enable it to establish subsidiary companies and to engage in other commercial activities such as countertrade, processing, storage and handling. To assist these activities the legislation will also provide for an industry fund to provide the AWB with a much needed capital base. I will elaborate on arrangements for the fund later in this speech.

To complete its marketing powers the AWB must be able to operate within States. The Government urges the State Governments to ensure that the Board is not weakened by the lack of appropriate facilitating legislation.

The Opposition and the Grains Council of Australia have suggested that the Bill is deficient because it does not provide the AWB with powers to trade within States. The simple fact is that the Commonwealth does not have the constitutional power to legislate to this effect. The issue of facilitating the legislation was raised with the relevant State Ministers at the February meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council, for their own reasons some States have chosen to prevaricate. It is the State Governments, not the Commonwealth, who must now act on this issue.

A significant issue for Australian grain producers is the cost associated with the storage, handling and transport of their product. The Royal Commission identified that in 1987-88 these costs were equivalent to around 22% of the fob price for wheat. It recommended a series of deregulatory moves which included the removal of sole receival rights for grain handling authorities, removal of restrictions on the transport of wheat in certain States and the disaggregation of charges for these services to enable growers to make informed decisions about least cost grain paths. The Royal Commission estimated that these changes could lead to potential resource cost savings of up to 10 dollars per tonne.

The Commonwealth Government has endorsed the broad thrust of the Royal Commission's findings and last year amended the Wheat Marketing Act to provide the AWB with the choice in contracting for grain distribution services and to disaggregate charges to growers. Much of the responsibility for putting the Royal Commission's recommendations into effect rests with the State Governments. However, New South Wales is the only State to announce a positive response.

If the AWB and other grain trading corporations are to realise the savings estimated by the Royal Commission, they must have the scope to use least cost methods of handling and moving grain. The amendments to the 1984 Wheat Marketing Act, which I have already mentioned, were a step in this direction. However, some States have chosen to deny growers the opportunity of benefiting from the potential savings by continuing monopoly practices in their handling and transport sectors.

May I provide some examples. In Victoria, Section 188 of the 1983 Transport Act restricts the mode of transport of certain goods. Bulk wheat, barley and oats are not to be carried by private road hauliers beyond a 60 km radius of the place of consignment unless the vehicle owner has been granted a permit by the State Transport Authority. Under section 10 (2) of the Grain Elevators Act, the Grain Elevators Board has the exclusive rights to handle grain in the State.

In Queensland, similar regulations effectively restrict to rail grain transport over distances greater than 120 km. Section 26 of the Grains Handling Act provides Bulk Grains Queensland with exclusive rights to the storage and handling of export grains shipped from Queensland.

The AWB and other grain trading corporations must be not disadvantaged by this lack of action on the part of the States. The new Wheat Marketing Act provides clear powers for the AWB and other grain trading corporations and their service providers to enter into contracts for storage, handling, transport, port services for grain and marketing of wheat intended for interstate or export unencumbered by State regulations.

Following tabling of this Bill in the House of Representatives, concerns were raised about the inclusion of references to grain marketing in the sections of the legislation dealing with these powers. The Minister has made it clear that these provisions were not aimed at changing current arrangements within the States for the marketing of other grains. They gave the Government a reserve power in case the States tried to circumvent the Commonwealth's intention to enable unrestricted transport, storage and handling operations. However, recognising the concerns expressed by the States, the Government accepted an amendment in the House confining regulations on marketing to wheat.

I turn now to the marketing provisions in this Bill. The Government recognises that world grain markets remain under the influence of distorting government policies. I have decided, in response to widespread concerns expressed by the GCA and growers generally, that the AWB should remain the single export marketer for all Australian wheat. The AWB will continue to be able to use private traders as principals or agents as it does now and it will be able to authorise the direct export of wheat if the Board and growers judge it in their best interest. While it continues to have this export monopoly, the AWB will continue to be the receiver of last resort. This will, however, not prevent it from setting standards for the wheat it receives.

There is no justification for continuing the AWB's domestic marketing monopoly. Wheat is the only industry subject to Commonwealth regulation which has this control. In its 1988 May Economic Statement the Government announced that domestic support arrangements for agriculture should be progressively reduced in accordance with the general reductions in protection and assistance across the economy.

The Bill provides for the domestic marketing of wheat to be freed up and this will be achieved through the removal of compulsory acquisition and termination of the arrangements for an administered domestic price. The objective of this move is to give growers greater choice in how they sell their wheat and when. Growers will still have the option of delivering to the AWB's pools, but in addition they will be able to sell their wheat for cash either to the AWB or to other buyers on the domestic market.

It is quite clear that many growers want this choice. Some 90% of the wheat used for feed purposes is traded under the permit system. It is also a fact that wheat continues to be traded on the black market and, as indicated recently by the Flour Miller's Council, that milling wheat is being sold through the feed wheat permit system.

The essential point is that compulsory acquisition is no longer needed for an efficient marketing effort. I am confident that the AWB will remain the dominant force in a deregulated domestic market given its expertise and the additional commercial powers which I outlined earlier.

An important benefit arising from freeing up the domestic market will be the greater scope growers will have to arrange their own storage, handling and transport. These additional competitive pressures will assist in achieving the potential resource cost savings in this sector identified by the Royal Commission.
Users of wheat, particularly feedlotters, will also benefit from a freer domestic market and the removal of the costs and red tape involved in the current grower to buyer and permit systems.

In the recent debate on wheat marketing much has been made of the effect of domestic market deregulation on growers' returns. The argument has centred on concern that when prices are depressed by heavy subsidisation on overseas markets, this will be reflected in the domestic market price.

This effect, however, depends on the level of subsidisation and also the size of the Australian crop. During the last season the smaller Australian crop and improved market opportunities meant that there was little need for the AWB to discount its prices, even though there was continued strong subsidisation by the US and EC. When market prices are rising rapidly, the domestic price arrangements can cost growers money. The inclusion of past prices in the formula can lead to the Home Consumption Price being lower than the free market price.

The AWB through its export monopoly will still control some 80 per cent of the wheat produced. Average export prices as reflected in the expected net pool return will put a floor in the market. Contrary to claims by the GCA no grower selling wheat outside the AWB system is likely to accept a farm gate price which is less than the price obtainable through the pool.

Estimates show that over the last four years, if none of the wheat sold domestically had passed through the AWB pools, the loss to the pools would be in the range of 0.23 cents per tonne to 2 dollars and 93 cents per tonne overall. This is the worst that could happen and, in my view, is highly unlikely to happen.

In a free market millers can be expected to continue to pay a premium to secure their special requirements for regular supplies and there will be scope for individual growers to achieve quality premiums within the ASW range, something that is not available to the AWB under the current administered domestic price. In addition, the potential savings through the use of more efficient storage, handling and transport facilities can be expected to more than outweigh any transient reduction in prices likely to result from subsidisation on export markets.

These new marketing arrangements will meet the needs of growers of specialty wheats such as durum and organically grown wheat. Currently these producers incur the AWB's pool costs even if they do not use its services. In future they will be able to sell their wheat freely on the domestic market and I would expect that the AWB will be able to accommodate the export needs of these producers either through its additional pooling flexibility, or through the scope it has to authorise the direct export of wheat.

While the AWB will have extended commercial powers and a continued export monopoly it should not abuse its market power. The Trade Practices Act will apply to its commercial activities. In this regard it will be important for the Board to keep its trading and pooling activities at arms length and for it to visibly and separately account for these activities.

Concern has been expressed that domestic market deregulation will affect Australia's ability to maintain its current high standard of grain hygiene and that this will affect our export effort. I do not believe this will be the case. The AWB will be able to enforce existing hygiene standards through its contractual arrangements with those providing storage, handling and transport services. The legislation will make the Board's powers clear in this respect. Wheat which moves outside the AWB will be subject to market pressures if it does not meet hygiene standards acceptable to buyers. Some growers may choose to store more wheat on farm, but this is unlikely to be extensive particularly since the option of warehousing is now available.

A guaranteed minimum price scheme has operated in the wheat industry for 10 years. This scheme has its drawbacks. Because of the averaging effect of the GMP formula, the GMP and, therefore advance payments, is not necessarily a good indication of expected market returns. For instance, because of the recent strengthening of the wheat market, the final GMP set recently for the current season is only about 80 per cent of expected net pool returns. The GMP has tended to be used as a market indicator but is clearly a poor one. The GMP arrangements have also been the source of rigidities in the operation of the current wheat marketing arrangements, particularly with respect to the AWB's pooling operation.

In all years the principal benefit of the GMP scheme has been the backing it provides to enable the AWB to borrow at favourable interest rates and pay a relatively high first advance to growers delivering wheat to the AWB pools. The Government will continue to provide this benefit via a specific borrowing guarantee. Essentially this means that the AWB's borrowings will continue to be underwritten by the Government. Should there be a call on the guarantee the Government will meet its obligation and will not seek repayment by the industry. This is a significant commitment and is indicative of the Government's willingness to continue to back the wheat industry.

In the initial year of the new arrangements this guarantee will be set at a level which will enable the payment of a first advance equivalent to 90 per cent of the estimated net pool returns in the current season. I would point out that because of the current rising market prices, this will result in a higher first advance than would have been available under the GMP scheme.

In the 1988 May Statement the Government announced that industry should progressively take over responsibility for funding the costs involved in reducing price uncertainty through underwriting schemes. Consistent with this intention the level of the borrowing guarantee will be phased down to 80 per cent of estimated net returns in year five of the new arrangements. The guarantee will be subject to review within five years. Should the industry wish to have a higher level of first advance than that available through the borrowing guarantee, provision has been made for it to introduce its own mechanism to make any additional payments.

Arrangements for setting the level of the guarantee will involve preliminary Ministerial determination (in consultation with the AWB and the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics) of the estimated net pool return for the season by 1 October. As under the current arrangements, a final guarantee and advance could be established later in the season. It will be up to the AWB in consultation with the GCA to determine the actual level of first advance for particular categories of wheat delivered to pools which will be based on the level of available borrowings. The level of the Government's financial commitment, however, will be limited on an aggregate basis to the level of the borrowing guarantee.

I am aware that the averaging arrangements in the previous GMP scheme provided support to growers in circumstances of extreme market downturn such as in 1986-87. If such a crisis were to occur again the Government would need to give close consideration to special support arrangements for the industry. I would also point out that the Government is also providing drought assistance and national interest insurance cover to the wheat industry.

The financing arrangements I have just described relate only to the AWB's pooling operation. However, as I have indicated, the Board will have a broader commercial role and there is a need to establish a capital base for it. It is a source of major weakness to the industry that the AWB has no asset base despite its role as one of the country's largest marketers. The new wheat marketing legislation will provide the mechanism for the establishment of an industry fund through a levy on all wheat sold. The Government will also assist in the initial establishment of this fund through the provision over five years of a loan guarantee of up to 100 million for the purposes of the fund.
This will not be a stabilisation fund. It will provide finance for a range of activities which would include:
the AWB's commercial undertakings, including cash purchases
making advance payments above the level provided through the AWB borrowing guarantee
providing insurance on credit sales.
It will be for the GCA in consultation with the AWB to determine the specific uses to which finance from the fund will be put.

The fund will be a powerful new avenue through which the industry will be able to influence its future. Detailed arrangements for the fund are still being considered by the GCA and the AWB and will be incorporated in regulations. I would emphasise, however, that the Government would want to see a commercial relationship between the fund and the AWB and proper equity arrangements established for growers. The fund will only be activated if industry agrees to the introduction of a levy for this purpose.
Levy arrangements are the subject of separate Bills.

The AWB will be moving into a new phase of its operations and facing new challenges. It will be undertaking expanded commercial operations with a minimum of Government control but with Government borrowing guarantees. If the AWB is to perform effectively in this new environment it is essential that the best qualified people are appointed to the Board. It must be able to develop clear corporate strategies and purpose. The new Act will provide for Board members to have a balance of skills in the areas of production, marketing and finance.

It will also be essential for the AWB to have a highly skilled management team. It must have a Managing Director as the Chief Executive who the Board should be able to pay at market rates, free from the Remuneration Tribunal constraints which operate at present.

In principle I favour the appointment of a non-executive Chairperson who in the long term would be part-time. I recognise that the Board faces a challenging task in the transition to the new arrangements and that stability in its leadership structure is desirable. I have indicated to the GCA that the AWB will continue to have a grower Chairperson.

I am aware of grower concern about ``loss of control'' of the AWB. Let me emphasise that the Board will continue to be accountable to growers. However, this responsibility will be exercised through the the AWB Selection Committee and consultative arrangements between the AWB and GCA rather than through participation in the day to day running of the Board.

The new Act will make clear provisions for the AWB to consult the GCA on the performance of its functions. In particular, I would expect the AWB to consult the GCA on such issues as the establishment of subsidiaries, pooling arrangements and general policy on trading in other grains and wheat of other origin. While the Act provides for a minimum of one consultative meeting each year, I would expect the AWB and GCA to consult more frequently than this.

Given its continuing role as a statutory authority, the AWB will also continue to be accountable to the Minister and the Parliament. The Board's Annual Report, Corporate Plan and Annual Operating Plan constitute important avenues of accountability both to the Government and the GCA.

The current arrangement under which the cost of shipping wheat to Tasmania is funded through a levy on domestic wheat sales will be terminated with the deregulation of the domestic market. The Government has, however, undertaken to continue funding this assistance from Consolidated Revenue. The exact amount of this assistance has still to be worked out but in 1989-90 I expect it to be close to the average level of about 3 million dollars which has applied in recent years. The assistance will phase down by 25% over the five year period commencing in 1989-90 and the scheme will be subject to review within five years.
There are no other direct financial implications arising from the legislation, although the Government is committed to assuming contingent liabilities under the proposed borrowing guarantees.

I believe that this new legislation will set the Australian wheat industry on a clear path for a prosperous future. It provides for a commercially strong AWB, free from unnecessary regulation and with clear lines of responsibility to growers. The marketing arrangements will provide more flexibility and choice to growers and an opportunity for both growers and end users to keep costs down. These changes together with the introduction of new financing arrangements for the AWB will ensure that the industry is in a strong position to meet competitive challenges into the next century.
I commend the Bill to Senators.
WHEAT INDUSTRY FUND LEVY BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill and the associated Levy Collection Bill is to enable the wheat industry to impose and collect a single ad valorem levy on wheat, for distribution between the Wheat Research Trust Fund and any industry fund which may be established under the provisions of the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989. This latter Bill is the basis for the whole legislation package covering new wheat marketing arrangements to apply from 1 July this year.

The levy will be paid on wheat that is sold, delivered or processed by or on the growers' behalf from 1 July this year. This will enable the continuation of the current research funding arrangements based on grower and matching Commonwealth contributions, from that date.

The Grains Council of Australia will determine the rate of levy, based on a percentage of sales value, for payment to the research fund. This percentage which will be set by regulation cannot be less than 0.25% and this compares with the current rate of research tax of about 0.35% of value. The industry has already indicated a preparedness to increase its contribution to research over a three year period in order to move towards the ceiling of the Government's matching contribution of 0.5% of average gross value of production.

The industry fund provided for under the Wheat Marketing Bill to finance a number of commercial activities by the Australian Wheat Board will only be activated if the industry through the Grains Council determines that a percentage of the total levy to be imposed under the Levy Bill is to be used for this purpose. This percentage of sales value cannot be less than 2% which is equivalent to about 3 dollars and 80 cents per tonne for standard quality wheat.

The decision to implement an ad valorem levy to replace the previous fixed rate per tonne wheat taxes, which were imposed for research purposes and the operation of the stockfeed permit scheme, was designed to make the levy as equitable as possible. For example a tonne of prime hard wheat is more valuable by about 35 dollars than a tonne of feed wheat and therefore an ad valorem levy will distribute the levy burden more evenly among growers of different qualities of wheat.

The amount of revenue collected for wheat research purposes under the new levy arrangements is not expected to vary from current estimates which reflect the industry's agreement to increase its contribution to research. Revenue is expected to increase to 11.8 million dollars by 1991/92 from the current level of around 10.5 million dollars.

It is estimated that if the industry fund is activated the component of the levy for payment to the fund would initially be set at 2% of sale value. This would result in revenue of an estimated 55 million dollars in a full year.
Administration of the levy collection arrangements will be undertaken within the existing resources of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
WHEAT INDUSTRY FUND LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1989
The purpose of this Bill is to provide the machinery necessary for collecting the levy imposed by the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Bill 1989.
This Bill should be read as one with the Levy Bill and is to come into operation on the same day as that Bill becomes operative.
The Bill specifies the liability of purchasers and receivers under the scheme, outlines penalties for non-compliance and provides appropriate powers of enforcement.
There are no financial implications other than those covered in the Second Reading Speech for the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Bill 1989.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
WHEAT (TERMINATION OF TAX) BILL (NO. 1) 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to terminate at 30 June 1989 the current research tax arrangements imposed on wheat delivered to the Australian Wheat Board. After that date an equivalent research levy will be imposed on wheat under provisions of the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Bill 1989.
Those sections of the principal Act, the Wheat Tax Act 1957, covering payment of tax monies already collected will remain in force to enable finalisation of these arrangements.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
WHEAT (TERMINATION OF TAX) BILL (NO. 2) 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to terminate at 30 June 1989 the research tax imposed on wheat sold under grower to buyer arrangements. This scheme will no longer operate under the deregulated domestic wheat marketing arrangements provided for under the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989.
Provisions of the Wheat Tax Act 1979 covering payment of tax monies already collected will remain in force to enable finalisation of these arrangements.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
WHEAT (TERMINATION OF PERMIT TAX) BILL 1989
The purpose of this Bill is to terminate at 30 June 1989 the tax imposed on permits issues by the Australian Wheat Board for stockfeed wheat sold outside of the pooling system.
This permit scheme will no longer operate under deregulated domestic marketing arrangements provided for under the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
WHEAT TAX (PERMIT) COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

This Bill in association with the Wheat (Termination of Permit Tax) Bill 1989 provides for the finalisation of tax payment arrangements under the current stockfeed wheat permit scheme which will terminate on 30 June 1989. Provision for the refund of any tax to permit holders, as is appropriate under the Wheat Tax (Permit) Collection Act 1984, will be maintained.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This group comprises a large number of Bills-I think 13-and it is fair to say that, combined, they constitute the largest single package of legislation ever introduced into this Parliament. They are also critically important in that they provide the Government's proposed framework for corporation and securities law for this nation. They are very radical in their composition, in that they propose a new nationalised system of corporate and securities law to replace the existing cooperative scheme, which, honourable senators on this side of the chamber believe, has served the nation well for the past nine years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition opposes the corporations package, except the Close Corporations Bill, which, as I indicated last year when the package was referred to a joint select committee, we support. Therefore, what I am saying is that, notwithstanding the considerations of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, the Opposition has formed the view that it is not in the best interests of Australia to move at this time to a nationalised system of corporate and securities law.

It is worth reiterating, I believe, not only that this is a massive package by volume, but also that, upon presentation of the Bills in the other place last year, the Government itself introduced, and had passed, some 280 amendments to its own proposed legislation. We had presented to us last night about 30 pages of Government amendments, which it seeks to have passed in this chamber. In addition, we have just received amendments from the Australian Democrats. It is obvious, therefore, that the committee stage of these Bills will involve a difficult and complex debate.

I remind the chamber that when the Senate referred the Bills to the Joint Select Committee on 14 October last year we sought much wider terms of reference for the Committee than were granted by the Senate. As a result of the more limited terms of reference, very serious questions remain under debate in the business and legal community-questions that are not specifically addressed by the Joint Select Committee's report. The most critical of those relates to the doubtful constitutionality of the whole package and, therefore, the potential disastrous consequences if Australian business and commerce were to rely upon a new legislative package which, in due course, was found to be constitutionally invalid. We regret that the Joint Select Committee did not look further at that matter. I think we demonstrated adequately at the time of the debate leading to the referral of the Bills to the Joint Select Committee that there is very serious doubt as to the constitutional validity of the package. There could be no more serious question to be addressed in detail than that.

Although the terms of reference were narrow, there was the very basic question in principle of whether it would be in the best interests of Australia if we abandoned the federal system existing at the moment, which has existed through means of a cooperative scheme, and moved to Commonwealth legislation administered and controlled by the Federal Parliament. I have to concede that, although the terms of reference did not allow that consideration, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), by letter to some of the States that were interested in the issue, said that he would have no objection to those arguments being put before the Committee. Therefore, those arguments were addressed by the Committee. Nevertheless, I think it is fair to say they did not receive the type of debate that would have eventuated if they had been the focus of the Committee's report. Rather, the focus of the Committee's report was on how the details of the package could be improved, were it to be accepted. As is the case with many of the reports of parliamentary committees, it is a useful document which helps in that constructive purpose. It is our regret that the Committee was not allowed to consider in greater depth the basic questions that needed to be determined before one could get to the detail of the package.

Therefore, we oppose the Bill because we believe that the existing cooperative system has basically served Australia well. We also oppose the Bill because of the very widespread opposition to it which exists within the community, in particular, from all States of Australia; from within the legal fraternity; from business and commerce generally. I will draw to the attention of the Senate in due course some specific examples of that opposition. It is fair to say that the national scheme, apart from the support it has from this Government, now has very little support from within the community, from the professions and business and, as I have said, it has a total absence of support from State governments. If the Commonwealth were to take over a scheme of doubtful constitutionality from the States, it would have been well served to obtain the support of the States before doing so. It has not done so. The States continue to be opposed to these proposals.

The third reason upon which we base our opposition is the very doubtful constitutional basis of the law and the calamitous consequences which could follow if the law were found to be invalid and, therefore, to varying extents, invalidating a mass of business or commercial transactions based upon that invalid law. I have said that the Opposition would prefer to retain the cooperative scheme. We do not say that the cooperative scheme does not require updating and amendment. In fact, it does. The Opposition has now settled upon the changes to the cooperative scheme it would look to achieve to enable it to meet properly the structural necessities in this field of law for the next decade or so. We therefore seek to have an amendment passed to the Australian Securities Commission Bill which I will move and which indicates our position in this debate. I move:

Leave out all words after `That', insert `the existing co-operative scheme has served Australia well and should be retained with appropriate amendments, to enhance the scheme in the light of experience since its inception and to update and strengthen its national regulatory role'.

The Opposition believes that the Government's dismantling of the existing cooperative scheme is a clumsy attempt at centralisation. It is also against the will of every State and Territory and the vast majority of business organisations in Australia. The coalition strongly supports the current cooperative model, which has not been in existence for nine years and which, generally speaking, has served corporate Australia well. Our objective is to provide commercial and individual access to an efficient and streamlined regulatory framework whilst ensuring adequate investor protection. Upon coming to government, we will therefore retain the current cooperative scheme of company law, whereby the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) administers companies and securities law through State corporate affairs commissions subject to the control of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. We will do so, in part, because of the wide acknowledgment that the checks and balances inherent in the cooperative arrangements provide a truly bipartisan forum where individual States can respond to the wide range of requirements of local business and professional communities.

As I mentioned a moment ago, we do, however, accept that after nearly a decade of operation the current scheme is in need of overhaul. That is why we propose our enhanced cooperative scheme as a clear alternative to the Government's proposals in relation to a corporate and securities law for this nation. That enhanced cooperative scheme is designed to allow greater flexibility while fostering more efficient administration. We stress that under our alternative scheme the States will continue to play their role in the regulation of companies and securities and will continue to collect funds on the current basis. In government, however, we would undertake a comprehensive review of the workings of the cooperative arrangements. To this end, the recommendations of the management committee of the Ministerial Council should, in our opinion, be considered immediately. The Ministerial Council has already approved a newly defined set of functions for the NCSC and the States to remove any duplication or overlap. Staffing and funding are also being examined. The experience of the members of the Ministerial Council will provide valuable input into the enhancement of the cooperative scheme.

In particular, the following changes would be supported by the Opposition to enhance the role of the Commonwealth Parliament and to speed up decision-making through the Ministerial Council: first, in order to provide the Commonwealth with a larger role in the formation and amendment of legislation, it is our view that the Commonwealth should become the permanent chair of the Ministerial Council. Secondly, consideration will be given to allowing the Federal Attorney-General a weighted vote on the Ministerial Council. Thirdly, we support the establishment of a parliamentary standing committee on corporations and securities to which the NCSC would report. Because I am a realist, I know that it is likely to pass debate in this chamber during the course of the next few days. In fact, we will be looking for some changes to that to give the Parliament a more effective capacity for scrutiny.

Fourthly, in our opinion the Federal Parliament should be vested with the clear right to debate legislation approved by the Council and to refer legislation back to the Ministerial Council for immediate approval or amendment. This whole area has, of course, been one of the great frustrations for those of us in the Senate who have debated corporate law over the years knowing that in fact the chamber can have little role beyond that of a rubber stamp. You would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs report which, in many ways, reflected the view that has been stated by honourable senators over the years-that the lack of capacity of proper ministerial accountability and capacity to amend is a great frustration. Our proposal does not totally resolve the matter but we believe, in this cooperative federal environment in which corporate law must exist, a step further is worth while and our proposal is in fact for a step further.

The fifth detailed change that I put to the Senate is that we will put guidelines in place to ensure that the administration and management of the State Corporate Affairs Commissions are standardised and streamlined across Australia. Again, the Senate Standing Committee expressed some frustration with the submissions that have been made to it as to a lack of standardised administration in this area of law.

Sixthly, we would provide a new funding procedure and cost recovery system for the National Companies and Securities Commission. In particular under a Liberal-National Party Government the NCSC will receive adequate funding through a combination of direct funds and the user pays system. It will be imperative that any funds collected by the NCSC under a user pays system be used to enhance the cooperative scheme. The Senate will be aware of the frustration of the operation of the NCSC under inadequate funding in recent years, and of the submissions that have been made by officers of the NCSC to Estimates committees of this Senate expressing that frustration and incapacity to meet properly its statutory responsibility under the restrictive funding that has been provided.

The seventh policy that we would implement is that State governments would retain the power to collect fees as they relate to services provided in the administration of companies and securities law. However, certain incentives will be provided to ensure that the States maintain adequate funding to their corporate affairs offices.

Eighthly, the NCSC also will be allowed greater staffing autonomy in order to facilitate the recruitment and retention of highly trained professionals. Rather than being regarded as a stepping stone the NCSC must, in our opinion, be in a position to offer a career structure with adequate rewards-a matter that was in fact discussed by the Joint Select Committee and that no doubt will receive further attention during the course of this debate.

Ninthly, in our policy the NCSC will be given greater powers to coordinate and direct the activities of the Corporate Affairs Commissions of the States and Territories. This may mean that the NCSC is vested with the discretion to decide whether an investigation should be conducted by the State or is more appropriately carried out by the NCSC because of its national character.

Tenthly, we would move to expedite the implementation of full computerisation of company records by gaining a firm commitment from all States and Territories to cooperate. Finally, under our Government, work will continue towards further harmonisation of regulatory requirements between Australia and other countries. This will build on the memorandums of understanding already signed with Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States of America. Harmonisation will ensure reciprocal recognition of fundraising and takeover documents as well as financial reports. What we are seeking to do is to set up a clear and detailed alternative to the Government's national scheme, which it is seeking to put through the Parliament at the moment, our scheme being referred to as an enhanced cooperative scheme.

There are a couple of matters that I should not let pass without dealing with them in a little more detail. The first is our concern with the doubtful constitutional basis of this legislation. I raised these matters in my speech to the Senate on 14 October 1988 in reference to referral of the Bills to the Joint Select Committee. I regret that the Government does not seem to have answered the very serious and widespread concerns that have been raised throughout the legal profession in this regard. I would have thought that, at the very least, as it is some six months or so since the time of reference of those Bills, the Government would have come out with further information to justify constitutionality beyond the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers, which is well known to the Senate and which was referred to in the previous debate.

I mentioned at that time that the worries about constitutionality have been sought to be overcome on a number of occasions through the referendum process. The proposals, which would have given corporation power clearly to the Commonwealth, were put and defeated in 1911, 1913, 1919 and 1926. In 1929 the Royal Commission on the Constitution recommended that the Constitution be amended to confer power on the Commonwealth in legislative form in this area. In 1959 the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review recommended that the Constitution be amended to grant the Commonwealth concurrent legislative power over corporations. As late as 1987 this Government's advisory committee to the Constitutional Commission on Trade and National Economic Management recommended constitutional reform to overcome the doubts that existed as to the constitutional competence of the Commonwealth Government to support legislation of this type. So what we have seen throughout the history of the Commonwealth is a recognition by learned bodies that there is considerable doubt existing as to the constitutional interpretation upon which this legislation is based.

I remind the Senate that the Government's last advisory committee, which I mentioned, included senior lawyers and businessmen and in fact reported after the Senate Standing Committee report, which included the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers. No doubt it was taken into account; nevertheless it remained in question. On the previous occasion the Attorney-General's Department itself, in its submission to the Senate Standing Committee, expressed concern about the constitutionality of a full takeover of the law in this area and therefore advocated a split scheme with the Commonwealth taking over the securities law. Nevertheless the Australian Government has, as it turns out, been much more ambitious in its grab for power in this area and has disregarded the concern and based the whole of this scheme upon a doubtful constitutional power.

Mr Deputy President, I also mentioned on the last occasion the joint memorandum of the Solicitors-General of the States and the Northern Territory, produced as a result of a meeting on 9 March 1988, in which they unanimously question the Commonwealth's legal competence in this area. One could go on and consider the submissions that have been made by the Law Institute of Victoria, such eminent legal firms as Mallesons Stephen Jaques and the Law Council of Australia. I repeat a relevant paragraph of the Council's advice to the Parliament, dated 31 August of last year, in which it said that it believed it would be irresponsible for the Commonwealth to legislate on the basis of its existing constitutional powers. It also said that the Commonwealth should not legislate unless and until the Constitution has been appropriately amended. That is advice from the Law Council of Australia, the pre-eminent representative body of lawyers in this Commonwealth, which I would have thought should not be readily dismissed.

The Government has an exotic scheme, I understand, whereby it proposes that the laws be passed and we then wait upon a challenge from one or more of the States to resolve the constitutionality. We on the Opposition side of the chamber do not believe that is the appropriate way in which to determine the correct interpretation of the Constitution. We believe that in such an important area as setting up a totally new framework for the constitutional and securities base for this country it is irresponsible to legislate upon unclear and, certainly, doubtful constitutional opinion.

I said a little earlier in my address that many business organisations and professional organisations in this nation are opposed to the scheme that the Government is proposing. They remain opposed. In fact, despite the six months since the matter was referred to the Senate committee, all that can be said is that their views would seem to have been reinforced by further debate and consideration of this matter. We have here a package of law which is critically important to this nation, which nevertheless is being put to this Parliament without the support of business and professional organisations, which is based upon doubtful constitutional interpretation and which lacks the support of any one of the States or Territories of this nation.

In those circumstances we do not believe that it would be responsible for this Parliament to pass the package. As I have said, we would rather advocate the alternative of a new enhanced cooperative scheme which can achieve all the objectives which this Government claims to be achieving through its nationalisation of law in this area, but in a way in which the constitutionality is unquestioned; in a way which would involve the cooperation and goodwill of the States, which we believe is so critical to effective law in this area; and in a way which would be supported generally by commerce and the legal and accounting professions.

One is really at a loss to understand why the Government has chosen this path rather than the path we have outlined, which would receive such widespread support throughout the Australian community. Nevertheless, the Government seeks to do so, presumably to try to justify the position the Attorney-General has advocated in this area, perhaps as a parting gesture-some legacy that he will leave-because there is no logical reason, objectively assessed, that we can see to support the direction that this Government has taken.

As I indicated, we will be dealing in detail in the committee stage with each of the chapters of the report and the amendments that the Government and the Australian Democrats have put up. Therefore, in this speech I will not address the detail of the Committee's report. The Opposition, as I said, opposes the package, except for the Close Corporations Bill, for the reasons that I have outlined and will seek the support of the Senate for the amendment that I have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing yet again the corporations package of Bills. The history of this legislation is now quite extensive. It goes back to the Federal Government's announcement in 1987 that it would proceed with a national scheme to replace the present cooperative scheme. This national scheme, of course, has been thoroughly debated and examined. Indeed, it is difficult to think of a recent package of legislation which has been more subjected to detailed scrutiny and examination across the board.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Parliament, I am happy to say, has played a leading role in helping the debate on this issue. The need for a national scheme was recognised first in this Parliament, and in this House, by the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange, the Rae Committee, in 1974. That Committee concluded that it was vital that the national character of activities being regulated be recognised. The Rae Committee opposed the concept of a regulatory body reporting to several governments. Since the Rae Committee report, the business environment in and Australian securities and financial markets has changed rapidly, yet the mechanisms for dealing with this have hardly changed at all.

The problems associated with that lag were again recognised in April 1987 by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, a committee of which Senator Hill was a member. Its report, entitled The Role of the Parliament in Relation to the National Companies Scheme, concluded that the cooperative scheme had served the needs of the 1970s but had failed to meet the needs of business as we head into the next century. That is a very important stance to take. When one looks at the cooperative scheme one can see that it has been a useful device in bringing us to the point where we are now. However, one can see that it is a creaking device and a device which progressively is becoming less adapted to the new environment.

The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recommended that the Federal Parliament develop and assume responsibility for the national companies and securities scheme, something with which Senator Hill also agreed at that time. The Committee's report has had considerable impact on the present legislation. It is also worth emphasising that the Committee's recommendation at that time was unanimous, supported by members of the Labor and Liberal parties.

The package of Bills with which we are dealing will replace the separate State and Territory legislation on the cooperative scheme with a single system of law for companies throughout Australia. It will replace the current scheme, and replace the current National Companies and Securities Commission with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). The basis of the Australian Democrats' support for a national scheme rests, first of all, on the position adopted in the 1987 report, on the need for a scheme looking into the future. Secondly, it rests on two other major matters. One is parliamentary and ministerial accountability, and the other is the attitude of business to the regulatory mechanisms.

If we look first of all at parliamentary and ministerial accountability it is obvious-and Senator Hill alluded to this in his speech-that every time we had legislation before us with regard to the cooperative scheme it was said by one honourable senator or another that we needed a particular amendment here or a particular amendment there, but we never amended any such legislation, and for a very good reason. The reason is that under the creaky cooperative scheme one had to manage to get all of the States and the Commonwealth to agree-and, of course, in Australia to get all of the States and the Commonwealth to agree to anything is almost a superhuman task. So the thought of actually amending that legislation and putting the whole thing back to the starting point was too much for most honourable senators to contemplate.

Therefore, we were willing and almost had to pass pieces of legislation that this chamber saw as deficient and that were, for example, running foul of a number of reports from our own committees with regard to the rights of Australians. So the Scrutiny of Bills Committee regularly reported adversely on those pieces of legislation coming before us. If this chamber had had its way, it would never have passed those pieces of legislation in the way it did. We did it only because the thought of getting all of the States in this country to agree to anything probably overwhelmed us, and we thought, `We had better grab it it now. The chances are not likely to come again'. Indeed, as somebody pointed out, and I think it is quite true, it is a lot easier to get the countries of Europe-countries which have spent the last 300 or 400 years fighting one another almost to the death-to agree on something than it is to get our States to agree to something.

The important thing that this Parliament has on its plate is this nation's future. We must have in place good company law which looks to the future of our economy. On my own behalf and that of my Party, I express the view that we do not believe that it is possible through the cooperative scheme to have in place the type of regulatory operations that are needed in the rapidly changing environment of the securities and futures markets.

In terms of ministerial accountability, of course, no single Minister had the responsibility for this particular scheme, and effectively nobody was in charge. Even Senator Hill obliquely recognised this problem when he said that under the Opposition's scheme the Commonwealth would be a permanent chair of the committee. Indeed, honourable members opposite were even looking at the possibility of having a weighted vote. I would give it a weighted vote-a vote of 51 per cent. We might get something done. Senator Hill probably has not read all of the transcripts of the inquiry of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, but it is interesting that three of the four issues that were first raised with respect to the cooperative scheme are still not solved. That is one of the things that led business to support this particular scheme.

I listened carefully to what Senator Hill was saying. He might have been technically correct in saying that the majority of the organisations have expressed opposition, but the majority of business is overwhelmingly in favour. That can be easily demonstrated by the fact, for example, that the small business association spoke glowingly of this particular package. That gives us the overwhelming majority of businesses to start off with-well over 90 per cent of all businesses in Australia. On top of that, of course, the Business Council of Australia-representing the dominant companies in this country's economy; those which in fact have the overwhelming trading operations in this country-was also in favour. I think that when those two ends come together-small business and the biggest business-one has to pause and ask, `How is it that there can be that alliance between those groups which one would imagine would have such disparate views?'.These organisations said quite frankly that they were looking for a single, definitive, cooperative scheme.

In passing, I make reference to another point raised by Senator Hill, that of funding his scheme. He said that he would have the users pay. I interjected, `The users already pay', and that is the problem. The users pay and they do not get value for money, because what the users pay will prop up State Budgets and State Budget deficits. That money is being paid by business for a good scheme of regulatory operations in this country, but it is in fact being siphoned off at State level into State government coffers and other things are being done with it. If that money were in fact put towards the regulation of business-that is, if it were put towards the purposes for which it is currently paid-we would probably have a far better cooperative scheme than we have had.

Of course, there is absolutely no way of getting the States to agree to part with that money, because it is an important funding exercise. In other words, business, through the regulatory mechanisms, has become a milking cow. Let us be very clear about it. States are interested in keeping control of this area for the money. They are not interested in keeping control of it so that we can have proper regulation in this country. When this scheme came before us, knowing that we were dealing with what has already been referred to as the largest package of legislation introduced into this Parliament since Federation, we thought it was very clear that an inquiry would be needed. Indeed, I met with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on 29 July in Sydney and put it to him that when this legislation came to the Senate we would move for a committee inquiry, not to look at the general ideological dispute-that is, whether we should have a scheme-but rather to look at the question of what such a scheme should be like and whether this was the best we could have. So admittedly the committee inquiry was limited and focused.

I do not agree at all with Senator Hill that we should have spent more of our time juggling with whether this was constitutional. Quite frankly, a greater exercise in futility I could not imagine. The committee on which Senator Hill sat earlier had already done that and its members unanimously agreed. The Joint Select Committee, on which I sat, could have dealt with that matter and agreed unanimously or otherwise; it would not have made one iota of difference to the constitutional standing of this package of Bills, because the correct body to decide on the constitutionality of Bills is the High Court of Australia, not a committee of this or the other chamber. Indeed, I had some harsh words to say about the Attorney-General's interference in the Committee's inquiries with regard to writing to the States inviting them to give evidence on something which was not in our Committee's terms of reference. I do not know why he took it upon himself to do that. But I have put it on record that I did not accept that that was a proper function for us to be engaged in. It was none of the Attorney's business to write to the States and ask them to come and talk to us about things that neither this chamber nor the other had asked us to inquire into. In fact, it was improper. I have said so and it is on the record of that Committee inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate said at the time that he believed the terms of reference should be interpreted broadly.

—Senator Tate could say that, but we actually had a vote in this place on what we were going to do. The vote dealt very specifically with whether we were going to look at those constitutional matters, and this chamber decided that we were not going to do that. Despite that, we had to sit through hours upon hours of fairly standard rhetoric from people coming from the States talking about the ideological propositions. They are fair matters of dispute; I am not contending that they are not. But these general ideological propositions are really matters for the political parties in this place to contend with.

SPEECH.PARA: What I was hoping the Committee would do-and in fact, what it did do-was to take evidence over six months from Australians, business organisations, businesses, lawyers and other groups that were interested in this area right around the country. We had an innovative approach to this matter, one which I have already mentioned and recommended we might use in future. A representative from the Attorney-General's Department, from the National Companies and Securities Commission and from the Australian Stock Exchange went with us and provided us with absolutely invaluable expertise and information on a day to day basis. In fact, I picked up that idea from the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform, on which we have used much the same device with the electoral commissioners. It is a very useful device and it was enormously helpful to us in our deliberations.

Also, as a result of this Committee inquiry, a very large number of people in Australia realised that this particular package would proceed and that this was what they would have to deal with. In contrast to what occurred on the previous occasion, people were more willing to come forward and express their views. A lot of work was put into the submissions to the Committee, and some excellent work was done. We received an extremely valuable input from individuals and organisations with regard to technical matters in the legislation. As can be seen by the amendments proposed by the Government, by the Democrats and probably also by the Opposition, much of that inquiry was very productive.

In January the Democrats suggested that one of the important issues we were dealing with in the Australian Securities Commission Bill and the corporations Bills-the two major parts of this package-was the independence of the Australian Securities Commission. A number of organisations had quite correctly observed that, whatever the failings of the cooperative scheme, one valuable consequence arose from it, that is, it was rendered politically neutral by the fact that no one Minister had responsibility for it and no one Minister, therefore, effectively could make directions which might be detrimental to business in this country.

As a result I believed that the best course at that point might be to have a parliamentary committee. I was encouraged in that view by the fact that there would be two major beneficiaries of such a committee. One would be the business community in general. It would have an all-party organisation to which it could refer. Hence it would not necessarily be beholden simply to the Attorney-General or to the Attorney-General's Department. Problems that might arise and issues that might come forward could be ventilated by the committee. Hence there would be an ability to let off steam. The committee would also be able to monitor the operations of the new ASC. The other beneficiary would be the Parliament. Ten people, five from each chamber, would spend a considerable proportion of their time outside the chamber working within the committee on issues concerning Australian financial markets, the securities markets and the futures markets. The expertise that those members and senators would gain would be invaluable in subsequent debates.

The proposition was acceptable to the Committee and to the Government. The Government's response appears in its amendments. We believe that it will remove the problem that did not exist under the cooperative scheme but that could have existed under the single scheme, that is, the possibility of political interference. That would not exist under these amendments.

A large numbers of matters were not able to be dealt with by the Committee. At that stage what we were about was to try to make sure that any obvious errors that might have crept in or problems that existed could be rectified. There are a whole range of problems. One problem is that of the shield of the crown which this chamber has resolved to look at through another committee. There are the problems associated with insider trading and a whole host of other matters, some of which have already been the subject of inquiry and recent reports. Obviously, most of them were not able to be incorporated in this legislation.

When one looks at the size of the legislation one rapidly realises that there will be amendments to it over time. We were seeking to get the basic structures in place so that we could proceed and on the basis of a learning experience. We realised that amendments would become necessary in a year or two as the Government, the parliamentary committee and business in general learned how these items worked. I draw the Senate's attention to what happened to the large number of amendments that were made by this chamber unanimously with regard to the electoral laws. In a subsequent inquiry and in the hindsight of their operation during an election it became obvious that certain problems appeared that had not been recognised. We were able to amend the legislation in a subsequent Bill. I believe that the same situation is likely to occur with regard to this legislation. It is not possible to foresee all the problems that will arise. Hence adjustments will need to be made. It will also, hopefully, be a function of the committee to make sure that those adjustments are made rapidly and with due information and understanding.

The range of Bills we will be dealing with in committee is extensive and detailed. During the second reading debate I do not wish to go into those details or into why we are looking at amending some of the Government's amendments or moving some amendments the Government has put aside from the Committee's report. I believe that the major thrust will be agreed on, that is, that this legislation is a comprehensive attempt to come to grips with the future of business in this country and the future of Australia as a trading nation. Australia has peculiar problems as a significant trading nation with a very small population. Those types of problems do not emerge in countries such as the United States that have a very large domestic market. We do not have such a large domestic market. Unfortunately, in many of the debates we have in this place the ignorance or non-recognition of the fact that we are a trading nation without a major domestic market leads people to make erroneous comparisons between Australia and other countries about the way we can structure our organisations for business.

I cite an example that does not appear readily. It is in the primary industry area. It is an issue which we will be debating shortly and on which a committee reported yesterday, the sugar industry. The sugar industry is a very large exporter. Sugar is Australia's second major rural product, after wheat. Eighty per cent of our sugar production is exported, which means that we are exposed to the world price in a way that no other country on earth is exposed to it. Other major producers and exporters of sugar do not export anywhere near 80 per cent of their sugar. The percentages they export are very low. So they can have a stable domestic price for their product. The fluctuating world price is only a small factor in the total take of their sugar industries. That is not the case with Australia. We have to look to structures and organisations that take into account the fact that we live on exports and are vulnerable to fluctuating world markets.

We need to structure ourselves in a way that is readily understood by other countries, that is not opaque or based on entities a very large number of which people think are merely places one visits as a tourist. Other countries do not understand that our federal system gives the States such enormous powers. They expect to be able to deal with our nation in a unitary way. It was clearly understood in the constitutional debates that Australia going into nationhood would require a single, corporate power. Written into our Constitution was the power with regard to trading corporations. It is clear that that power is handed to the Commonwealth Parliament. When we read the constitutional debates we see that that was acknowledged by people in the last century.

The Commonwealth has undoubted power with regard to trading corporations. Nobody has disputed that. There is a legitimate dispute on how extensive that power is and whether it covers 100 per cent, 90 per cent or 85 per cent of what needs to be covered. We probably will not know that until the High Court tells us. It is undoubted that prior to 1901 the vast bulk of the area was envisaged as coming under the control of this chamber. This is not a grab for power by the Commonwealth, it is merely assuming the power that has been there and was acknowledged in the early constitutional debates before we became a nation. If we go back and look at those discussions, we see that many were far-sighted. They saw us operating as a nation. I hope that the future progress of this legislation will be viewed in that light.

I return to the report of the Rae committee of 1974. It was presided over by a senator who is now a Minister in the Gray Government in Tasmania-at least he will be till Saturday, if not beyond. I thought that that committee made an excellent contribution to the early debate. I think it is a pity that it was not followed through at that stage. This particular group of Bills might not go forward to fruition and so not be implemented for some reason. We might have an early election and the conservative parties might win, on the basis of today's exercise-though one would have to say that their thrust for power has been thrown aside; there has been a hiccup on the way to the station. If that occurs, I would predict that a future conservative government would very rapidly come to the position where it would want to introduce this structure of legislation. Undoubtedly there are large numbers of reasons why it would want to do that. It is a sensible next step. I would imagine that the Minister for Finance would be Senator Puplick. He would be looking through his accounts and would suddenly discover that the leaching of untold millions of dollars by the States from the business which had been paid for on a user pays principle for a good regulatory system in this country was being used to prop up State budgets. The Treasurer and Finance Minister would soon come to the conclusion that this was no longer on. I am quite sure that the system Senator Hill told us about where we would have a weighted vote for the Commonwealth would very rapidly move, as I said at the beginning of my speech, to 51 per cent so that the Commonwealth could get something done in this area. If those opposite did not do that, I think they would find themselves so far offside with business in a very short number of years that they would be back out of government again.

There is an imperative behind this legislation. I admit that 1989 might not necessarily make it so sharp that one has to give in to it, but within five years it will be such an overwhelming imperative that whoever is in power would reintroduce this legislation in an almost identical form. I think it is far better for us to introduce it now. There will be some bleeding in the changeover. I believe that we should do it now and get it over with. We want to put this country on a sure and single footing so that people are clear when they deal with any corporation in this land or wish to come into joint ventures with anybody that there is a single piece of legislation to which they can refer. The legislation is clear, and independent of political interference. I think the legislation should be supported by the people who wish to look ahead. I think that it is being supported for all the wrong reasons, but it will be supported eventually. Let us get on with it now. It has the support of all those people in business who can look ahead and see this country as a single nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills that we are debating, the corporations legislation, is the largest package of Bills ever introduced into this Parliament. The Bills deal with matters of fundamental importance to the future of this nation because they deal with the whole question of the regulation of the companies and securities industries in Australia and they are, after all, the very lifeblood of our economy and in many ways our society. The speakers list for this debate contains only nine names, including the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), who will be summing up. I regret that. I think that it is a matter that well and truly warrants a much wider range of speakers. Perhaps in the committee stage we will get a much wider contribution to the debate from members of both sides of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The major importance of the proposals-which Senator Hill has already said the Opposition will be opposing, with the exception of the Close Corporations Bill-has led the Opposition to adopt the relatively unusual procedure for this chamber of moving an amendment to what I believe is the key Bill; namely, the Australian Securities Commission Bill. The amendment has the effect of totally negativing the proposals contained in that Bill. I very strongly support Senator Hill's amendment to the motion for the second reading. It states:

Leave out all words after `That', insert `The existing co-operative scheme has served Australia well and should be retained with appropriate amendments, to enhance the scheme in the light of experience since its inception and to update and strengthen its national regulatory role'.

In the words of the amendment there are two or three key aspects which I believe have been completely ignored, deliberately or otherwise, by the Government and by the Australian Democrats, certainly from what Senator Macklin has said today, in their support for the proposals to completely do away with the cooperative arrangements between the Federal, State and Territory governments that have existed and served Australia very well now for almost a decade; to sweep away all that carefully nurtured and developed expertise and cooperation which has occurred, and replace it with a centralist body called the Australian Securities Commission, to replace the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), and a ministerial council that operates as the linchpin of the cooperative arrangements. The Australian Securities Commission will be centralised and all power, in terms of the regulatory process for the companies and securities of Australia, will be centralised in the Federal Government, in one Minister, the Federal Attorney-General. The power will be essentially centralised in the bureaucracy here in Canberra. That is a quite fundamental change because we will be getting rid of a system which has enabled a very wide ranging input from all State and Territory governments along with the Federal Government over almost a decade now which has had its roots out in the marketplace and in the various States of Australia.

All that will mean in essence so far as the policy making and the advising role is concerned is that it will all be swept away. What we will find, as I said earlier, is a centralised, bureaucratic, Canberra-based organisation. We have seen throughout our history what happens to organisations which, with the best will in the world, start off in that guise. The inevitable result of that is a continuing accretion of power to the Federal Government at the expense of the States, not just in a governmental sense but also in terms of the role the States, the business community as well as the governments play in the affairs of our nation.

The biggest danger facing Australia as we move towards the end of this century is a building on of what has happened under successive governments but, particularly, under Labor governments throughout our history, that is, a centralisation of power in Canberra. Power does corrupt. We have seen that time and time again. We have seen it in the case of the Rothwells exercise in Western Australia with the Western Australian Government. That corruption within the corporate world has occurred despite the fact that we have had the cooperative arrangements. I accept that point. The point I make from that proposition is that if we centralise the regulation of companies and securities we will greatly increase the scope and prospect of corruption creeping into the regulation of our companies and securities industries. I am sure no-one in this country would regard that in any way other than disastrous.

Historically, in Australia we can be rightly proud of the lack of corruption in public life. This move, particularly in such a sensitive area as the regulation of companies and securities and all that goes with it, towards abolishing the cooperative arrangements that have served us well over a decade and preceding that period and replacing them with a centralised power is of extreme importance. It poses a great danger for this nation.

Various things said about the proposals are simply not true. The package of 16 Bills was introduced into the House of Representatives in May last year. It was said then by the Government, and it has been said consistently since then, that this legislation was devised, prepared and talked through only after the fullest consultation with interested parties in the private sector.
