The basis for that statement is that the Government, before it prepared its Bills and as an essential part of the preparation of the Bills, set up a steering committee and consequently a consultative committee of people from the private sector to assist it in its deliberations.

What the Government omits to say is that that steering committee and the consultations that the consultative committee undertook were extremely narrowly based. The Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, which this Senate in its wisdom set up towards the end of last year to consider the Bills and report on them to it before the debate took place, found time and time again evidence presented to it to the effect that the consultative process had been minimal. Any idea that the Government in reality consulted widely in the preparations of these Bills is an absolute mistruth. Indeed, the body with the most experience and expertise in the whole area of companies and securities regulations in Australia is the existing regulatory body, namely, the National Companies and Securities Commission. Yet the NCSC was not formally consulted and did not engage in any consultation on the details of this package of Bills that was introduced last May until July 1988, two months after the Bills had been introduced into the Parliament.

The NCSC had no input into the thinking and development of those Bills. In the very valuable evidence it presented to the Joint Select Committee, of which I have had the privilege to be the Deputy Chairman, the NCSC made it quite clear that it had fundamental objections to the contents of the Bills, not just because it was being put out of existence itself, not just because of the centralisation of the scheme and the proposals contained in the Bills, but because it had fundamental objections to many of the details and contents of the Bills, particularly the Corporations Bill which, of course, is the major regulatory Bill of the package. The consultative process was minimal at best. In the response that the Government tabled last Friday to the Joint Select Committee's report there are some statements which are simply not true. The Government says in its response:
It should be noted that most major business groups fully support the implementation of this legislation . . .

That was not the experience of the Joint Select Committee. Indeed, it is correct that the Business Council of Australia, the major big business organisation in Australia, supported the proposals. But the more widely based major business organisation in Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, opposed the legislation, as did the organisation that represents small business in Australia. The Law Institute of Victoria opposed the Bills; as did virtually every professional practitioner that appeared before the Committee; and as did the six States and the Northern Territory Government. The six States and the Northern Territory Government are bitterly opposed to this legislation.

The implication in the Government's response, tabled last seek, to the Joint Select Committee report that there is widespread support for this legislation is simply untrue. The Joint Select Committee received 25 submissions which dealt with the desirability or otherwise of the centralisation of the regulatory arrangements and 17 of those 25 submissions were strongly opposed to the basic thrust of the Government's proposals.

What we really have here is the fact that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has announced his retirement. Lionel Bowen is retiring from the Federal Parliament at the end of this Parliament after a very long and record level of service to Australian Labor Party governments in this country. The Attorney-General desperately wants a memorial to his attorneyship enshrined in this legislation. He tried to do it last year with the four referendum Bills. We all know the fate that befell those referendum Bills. They were rejected, and rightly so, by the Australian public by the largest majority ever recorded against referendums in Australia. The corporations package is his last chance to erect a legislative memorial to his time in Parliament. That is what we are really looking at. That is why we are seeing a grab for power by the Federal Government; an attempt to concentrate in Canberra all these regulatory processes. That is why we are seeing insufficient reasons given for them. That is why we are seeing an obfuscation of the truth in terms of the argument and the reasons for the proposals.

There is another flaw in the arguments that have been put forward. Senator Macklin fell into this trap, as did many members of the Australian Labor Party and, I must say, the business community. It is being put about that we do not have a national regulatory scheme for companies and securities. That is simply untrue. Since the outset of the cooperative arrangements, we have had a national regulatory scheme in the sense that any decisions taken by the Federal, State and Territory governments in relation to the regulation of companies and securities has to be reflected in Federal legislation, mirrored in the legislation of the States and of the Northern Territory. Whilst it is true that there is no single Act in relation to regulation, the fact is that there are eight Acts that mirror each other in relation to legislation. That is as much a national scheme as is any scheme that is centralised in one piece of legislation passed by one parliament. The contention that we must have the proposals now being introduced by the Government in order to achieve a national scheme is another mistruth that has been put around.

It is said also that we need the new arrangements because Australia is now part of an increasingly international market, that world markets are becoming increasingly globalised and that there will be problems for Australia in operating in this international and increasingly competitive environment if we do not have a centralised national scheme. Presumably the implication of that is that Australian companies, operating here or abroad, are somehow having problems with regulatory processes under the existing arrangements, but not one skerrick of evidence, not one word was produced to the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation to indicate that that was the case. So the Government has really set up a straw man-its case has no substance at all in reality.

The Government has also been arguing that a centralised scheme will somehow make uniform the administration of the regulatory process throughout Australia in a way that does not now exist. That too is incorrect. The Joint Select Committee received virtually no evidence to that effect. It received virtually no evidence that the existing arrangements cause efficiency, delays in administration and in getting necessary approvals from the regulatory authorities and so on. First, there is no evidence to suggest that there are problems now; secondly, the evidence, including that of government witnesses, was overwhelmingly to the effect that the actual administration of the scheme on a day to day basis under the new proposals would be little, if any, different from the administration that exists now. So again a straw man has been set up-a case with no substance at all.

We on this side of the chamber accept that the cooperative scheme needs improvement. There is no doubt that significant improvements could and should be made in the existing arrangements. We would have no difficulty, for example, in accepting that the chairman of the Ministerial Council should permanently be the Federal Attorney-General. At the moment the position rotates between the Attorneys-General throughout Australia, and there is no particular virtue in that. However, there could well be virtue in having a permanent chairman, and if there were to be a permanent chairman it would be entirely appropriate that the position should be occupied by the Federal Attorney-General. But that is very different from saying that one centralised body is necessary. The whole beauty of the cooperative arrangements, and their underlying and essential strength, is that there is an input from governments around Australia, which are in day to day touch with a much wider range of the community, including the business community, than could conceivably be the case if everything were centralised here. So that is an improvement that could be made.

As Senator Hill has said on behalf of the Opposition, we would be prepared to consider giving to the Federal Attorney-General more than just one out of eight equal votes. We would be prepared to consider the Federal Government being given a weighted vote in any arrangements that might be made. We would also be prepared-more than prepared-to see established a parliamentary standing committee on corporations and securities to oversee and monitor the work of the regulatory agency, which, from our point of view, would continue to be the NCSC.

There are other proposals that could well be considered to strengthen the existing arrangements. But the point to which I cannot refer too often is that it is almost unanimously agreed by all political parties and those in the business community that achieving the desirable strengthening of and changes to the regulatory process does not require the abolition, the sweeping away, of the cooperative arrangements and input role for State and Territory governments and the business community throughout Australia. We do not need to make fundamental structural changes to achieve the desirable changes in detail.

There are many matters of detail in the 16 Bills that are before the Senate. Of course, only three of those Bills-the Australian Securities Commission Bill 1988, the Corporations Bill 1988 and the Close Corporations Bill 1988-are principal Bills; the other 13 are machinery Bills relating to financial regulations, and so on, associated with the three principal Bills. The Opposition supports the Close Corporations Bill. We do not hold out much hope that that Bill will be a panacea or any great shakes so far as its being snapped up and used by the smaller corporations in Australia is concerned. However it will provide them with an alternative mechanism to go about their incorporation and reporting arrangements, and so on, and there appears to be nothing wrong with the proposal, even if, as would appear likely, it is not going to be used all that much.

We reject the other two fundamental Bills-the Australian Securities Commission Bill 1988 and the Corporations Bill 1988. We reject the Corporations Bill not so much because of its content, much of which amounts to a sweeping up of the existing codes, supplemented by many changes that the Government has proposed, which we agree are desirable and worth while. As I understand it from the Government's response, it would be prepared to make further amendments based on the Joint Select Committee's report which would further improve the Corporations Bill. We will be voting against the Corporations Bill because it is part of a package which is integrally related to the Australian Securities Commission Bill, which is the Bill of the greatest danger and concern to the Opposition.

I will leave my further comments until the committee stage of the Bill. I would hope that the committee stage of the Bill would be a very carefully considered process, because there are some very important proposals contained in the details of these Bills-for example, the question of where the power should lie to make declarations of unacceptable conduct on the part of a company. It is a somewhat esoteric question, perhaps, to those who are not directly involved, but in real terms it is a matter of very great substance. There are many other matters of similar importance if we are to have a regulatory system in Australia for corporations and securities which will work efficiently and smoothly in the national interest and, at the same time, meet the needs of the users, the corporations and the securities industry, and also provide the necessary regulation to enable investors in Australia to have confidence that the regulatory processes in this country are right and proper.

I would like to address two of the points made by Senator Macklin in his comments. He seemed to complain that the Joint Select Committee-and, by inference, this Parliament-ought not to have been as concerned as were some of the coalition members of the Committee, and as I hope the Senate will be, about the constitutional validity of the legislation. There are very real doubts indeed as to the constitutional validity of this package. They can only be resolved by putting the Bills to the test in the High Court of Australia. It does not seem to have been worked through as to how that would actually happen. What would appear to be quite certain and unavoidable, though, is that the constitutional doubts about these Bills are such that the testing of them will be a long and protracted process. That, therefore, will lead inevitably to a lengthy period of uncertainty for investment in Australia at the very time when we need the opposite. At a time when we need investor confidence in this country, we are talking about sweeping changes to the structure of the regulatory process which will destroy investor confidence and will not allow it to be restored for a lengthy period because of the legal uncertainties involved.

I also find it extraordinary that the Government has not put in train any specific transitional arrangements to get us from the present system to the proposed new system. In its response to the Joint Select Committee's report last week, the Government intimated that those transitional arrangements would not be necessary. I find the response we have received to date quite unsatisfactory. I hope, before the debate proceeds too much further, that the Government will be able to give us some clearer and firmer details as to why transitional arrangements will not be necessary. They are matters for consideration at further stages of this debate.

I repeat on behalf of the Opposition that we are totally opposed to the abolition of the existing cooperative arrangements for the regulation of companies and securities in Australia. Those arrangements have served us well over many years. Certainly they need improvement and can be improved, but the improvements which need to be made can be made within the existing structural framework. It is a very dangerous thing indeed to accept the Government's proposals that in this vital and very sensitive area we need to centralise all power and policy-making in Canberra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this timely and appropriate package of corporations legislation. I had hoped that the Opposition might have reconsidered its position of opposition to this proposal in the light of its change of leadership. I would have thought that perhaps a more progressive view might have prevailed. Unfortunately, today we have heard a reiteration of fairly fundamental conservative arguments. It is fairly standard, in a conservative position such as that, to endeavour to make the obvious obscure and the clear confused and to try in the process to create a climate in which fear of what might occur can be put forward in contrast to rational argument. I found in the course of my service on the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation that the arguments about the national scheme and its merits were, in the broad, with some minor qualifications, quite clear and simple. Some of the obfuscation that was put forward in an endeavour to make the possibility of a national scheme seem somehow threatening, dangerous and subversive was extraordinary and extremist.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two separate issues: one is whether we should have a national scheme. The other is whether this would be the appropriate national scheme. Let me address what is perhaps more of a second reading argument, and that is whether we ought to have a national scheme. I also wish to deal with the appropriateness of this particular package. It is interesting to note that it was the unanimous view of another Senate committee that the Senate, as mentioned in that report, should enact comprehensive legislation covering the field currently occupied by the cooperative scheme. That recommendation was made unanimously by a committee, three members of whom of course still sit on the Opposition benches and two of whom are on the front bench. However, they have now changed their minds. They are not saying, to my regret, that they now support a national scheme, as they did two years ago. They are not saying, `The Government has the formula for the national scheme wrong, and we therefore are proposing a series of amendments'. They are saying, in the face of all the evidence, `The cooperative scheme is working wonderfully; let us only tinker with it and keep this flawed model, this antiquated machine'.

I accept that the cooperative scheme, when it was introduced, was a significant advance in the legislative framework for corporations and securities law in Australia. It was a significant advance, but time has moved on and the legislative framework needs to be modernised to deal not with what was a sound initiative in 1980, but with what is required in the 1990s and beyond. It would have been open for the Opposition to put forward proposals to say, `This is the sort of national scheme which we want'. I have to say that the Opposition members on the Joint Select Committee made some constructive suggestions, some of which are incorporated in the report. Many of the suggestions were unanimous and are now incorporated in the amendments which substantially improve the original legislation. However, Opposition members never, in my view, coped with the fact that they now are trying to concoct an argument which says a national scheme is in some way dangerous. They are very frightened of democracy. It is their view that the people who are elected to govern should not have power because that might in some way lead to a terrible nightmare. Even Senator Short, in his contribution, was forced to acknowledge that of course those things about which he was concerned were matters currently operating under the existing cooperative scheme. The fatal flaw in the Opposition's argument is exposed on any reasonable analysis of its amendment. It says that the existing cooperative scheme has served Australia well. That is arguable but I think it was an advance. The Opposition thinks it should be retained with appropriate amendments which are subsequently being discussed. But the very problem is that the Opposition cannot guarantee that those amendments will ever be carried. The flaw in the cooperative scheme is that it does not matter how progressive, sensible and competent the arguments of the Federal Government or of a State government for a particular piece of business law reform are, we do not have the capacity independently to get that legislation amended and we may wind up with a flawed scheme forever. It is the old problem of the lowest common denominator.

Some of the amendments that the Committee unanimously recommended in the report, which were supported properly by Opposition members, cannot effectively operate under the cooperative scheme. They need a national scheme to operate effectively. The parliamentary committee recommendations and the annual report recommendations cannot operate without proper accountability. Questions have been asked in this chamber during the brief period that I have been a member of it seeking information about the operation of the NCSC, and we have been confronted with the problem that nobody is properly accountable. No Minister is finally accountable for the NCSC, and the Parliament is not able to pursue a Minister in the way that it will be able to when there is a Minister to whom the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) is responsible.

I reiterate that that was the unanimous view of the Senate Committee, and now we have the position where it is all right to advocate a reform or write a report saying that something is a good idea, but we must not dare do it; we must not act upon the recommendation of that committee for comprehensive legislation covering the field currently occupied by the cooperative scheme. It is all right to write a report about it, because nothing changes. But if somebody actually proposes to act, it is all too terrible to contemplate.

As the Joint Select Committee recommended, a need does exist for a national scheme to meet developments in international trade and practices. The marketplace is changing and we need to change with it. We want Australian business to have the capacity to operate effectively within Australia and internationally, and it wants a national scheme. The development of a national and more international structure of company and security activities is highlighted by the support given to the Bills by the Business Council of Australia, which we welcome and which is entirely appropriate. We need a single, responsible, political locus of responsibility to give effect to a national priority for effective, efficient and proper administration of companies and securities.

We need to create a situation in which we can avoid the current problems in conducting companies' activities from one jurisdiction to another in Australia and where business may need to be carried on under different forms of regulation in different States. So the internationalisation of the marketplace and the rate of change that is going on in the marketplace require a capacity to respond more quickly to those changes, a capacity for one government to act and to be responsible for its actions, rather than have a shadow of a cooperative scheme behind which it can hide and say that it is not its responsibility. It needs to establish accountability. It should not be frightened of democracy; it should build in some checks and balances as this proposal does. First of all there is the fundamental question of accountability to the Parliament and, second, the question of the proposed Joint Standing Committee on Companies and Securities, which is an entirely appropriate initiative. It was not a proposal that I, or so far as I know the Labor Party, initiated. However, it is an entirely appropriate initiative and a unanimous recommendation of the Committee. The interstate nature of business does require a substantial reform of business regulation legislation, and this is one example of that.

I shall move now to the changes that have been made to the Bill by the Joint Select Committee. I shall not deal with them in detail. That is appropriate for the committee stage when we will be dealing with various amendments that the Government is initiating. I wish to talk broadly about the principles that they address, why I think they enhance the Bill and why I support them and their philosophical content.

Firstly, there is the whole question of the introduction of the panel. I thought the argument for that was encapsulated by the very impressive witness who was commented upon and quoted at length in the report. He was the Sydney lawyer, Mr Green, who said it was true that the panel was a bit of an innovation and that it was possible to see arguments for and against it, but that it was worth a try because, if it worked, it would be a very cost efficient, quick and respected mechanism for making declarations of unacceptable conduct. I think he is entirely right.

There is the question of the balance between regulation and deregulation. The Bill is enhanced by the changes made to it in response to the report of the Joint Select Committee, and I congratulate the Government for its speedy and positive response to those recommendations. There is a need to strike a balance between investor protection and an efficient market. That is what the Bill is trying to do. It weighs a number of important questions. It has changed the balance. I think the legislation is excessively regulatory in protecting people from things that they did not need to fear, impairing efficiency in the process. It is also important to recognise that this is not a typical market. It is not a market in which one finds the lower to middle income players, who would be consumers in a normal marketplace. If what was being exchanged was bread and cheese there would be entirely different players in the market. It is not like the labour market. It is very skewed towards the upper income groups and the big players.

Nevertheless, it does typify the reason for the need for the regulation of markets. It comes down in this instance to the question of unequal access and unequal financial resources-although that of itself is not a case for it. Considering the various aspects in which either the regulation which currently exists is sustained, and which I understand is supported by the Opposition because it supports the retention of the existing scheme, or where it is enhanced in the proposed Bill in response to the Joint Select Committee's report, there are areas in which there is unequal access to information. That is quite evident in the financial market from day to day, even though financial reporting is of a very high standard. Often in Australia people can get access to that information before it is published or can get information in addition to that which is published. Financial resources give unequal access to adequate professional advice and of course there is unequal distribution of power and influence-the capacity to influence the market and the capacity to influence decisions that are made.

That brings me to some of the other principles in and improvements to the Bill that have been made in response to the Committee. Some of those principles to which I wish to refer include transparency, efficiency and-I just referred to this-the balance between protection and efficiency. The Committee has improved the Bill, I think, by making more transparent the way in which the ASC and/or the Minister act; providing protection against any possibility of inappropriately political interference by requiring the tabling of ministerial directions, which is a fairly standard requirement in most pieces of legislation and which is appropriate to be introduced here; specifying the criteria for the annual report, which will mean that annually there will be a mechanism effectively to review the operation of the ASC; and establishing the Joint Parliamentary Committee. Those things, together with the pre-existing requirements, create an adequate transparency and an appropriate one.

On the question of efficiency, we have the proposal adopted from the Committee report for establishing a full time president with some interlocutory powers. There are reforms with regard to the operation and management of what were previously defined as dormant companies. I am very pleased to see the adoption of a number of initiatives consistent with the profits of crime approach which the Government has taken in other areas, so that people operating insider trading or in the marketplace without appropriate licences cannot profit from so doing.

I compliment my colleague Senator Alston for the initiative he took in some of those areas on the Committee. This was an example of the bipartisan operation of the Committee in questions of detail which significantly enhance this Bill, even though there were serious disagreements of principle about whether the Bill should proceed. Of course, I strongly disagree with the minority report on that matter, and I am pleased to see that on present indications the Bill will proceed and receive majority support in this House and in the House of Representatives. I accept that members of the Opposition, particularly Senator Alston, took initiatives which substantially improved the Bill. I hope I have not done his political career too much damage at this crucial time by giving him that endorsement.

It is also appropriate that the Bill, in its amended form, clarify the power of the ASC to publish recommendations which it might make to the panel about unacceptable conduct. I am not sure that there was ever any doubt that it had that power but, if there was, it is appropriate that it be clarified. The report raises that matter, and the Government adopts its recommendation. Similarly, with regard to the powers of the ASC to engage in commercial settlements to bring about satisfactory conclusions to investigations where it is concerned about the proper operation of the market-a power which has been effectively used by the NCSC on a number of occasions, and about which there was concern that it might not be available to the ASC-the Government reviewed the matter and in its response to the Joint Select Committee's report establishes, at least to my satisfaction and I think to the satisfaction of most, that that power exists.

There is the additional question of the balance between protection and efficiency. It is a very difficult balance, as I said previously. We have the extension of pre-vetting of prospectuses and the reintroduction of the pre-vetting part A statements for takeovers. There has been a bit of exaggeration about the extent to which the pre-vetting of prospectuses was changed by the Bill from the existing practice and the extent to which it is changed back in response to the Committee's report. Nevertheless, it is appropriate that that extent of pre-vetting should be modified in the way that the Bill, in its final form, proposes.

I think that the Government and the Joint Standing Committee will want to monitor that matter to see whether the balance which has been struck in response to the Committee's report is appropriate and whether a more deregulatory thrust as was originally imposed in the Bill, or a more regulatory thrust as in the existing Act, is more appropriate. I think that on the evidence available the balance being struck is the best that could be struck, but this is a controversial matter and needs to be reviewed.

Equally controversial is the question of the pre-vetting of part A statements with regard to takeovers. Those who undertake a close scrutiny of the report of the Joint Select Committee, who I suspect will be very few, will find that I had some reservations about the majority report-by eight of the 10 members of the Committee-that part A statements should be pre-vetted. I would prefer that that were not the case. Eight of the 10 members disagreed with me. The Government has accepted that majority view. I say: let us give it a try. I accept that that is the majority and prevailing view. I accept that the majority might be right, but I would certainly say that it is a matter that requires close monitoring. In my view, two or three years down the track-five years, because I do not want to see this legislation changed too often-the reform proposed in the original Bill will be reintroduced, and I will be pleased to support it at that time.

There was controversy on the Committee concerning the respective roles of the panel and the ASC concerning declarations of unacceptable conduct and whether the Securities Commission itself, in addition to its investigatory powers, should have power actually to make a declaration of unacceptable conduct or whether it should simply have power to make a recommendation to a panel which would finally adjudicate. I was in the minority view on that matter. I supported the existing proposal, which is retained in the Bill as it now stands, that there should be a separation of those responsibilities. I am very pleased that the Government has accepted that minority view. It is interesting for people to note the bipartisan nature of that division; people from different parties were on both sides of the divide. It is a difficult issue and I believe the Government has taken the appropriate course.

It is also appropriate to try the recommendations of the Committee for the protection of small shareholders in the compulsory acquisition of shares in the mopping-up at the end of a takeover bid. I know there is concern amongst members of the Government that this is an unnecessary restriction. It may prove to be so, but it is appropriate when moving into a new area of regulation that we are conservative in such matters. We should take the more modest course and review its activities to see the consequences of the alternative structures, and act accordingly in a review conducted by the Advisory Committee and the joint parliamentary committee, which will inevitably take place from time to time.

There are reforms of companies and securities legislation which still remain to be done. Three were referred to specifically in the Committee's report and they are important. However, it was not appropriate to try to do everything in one swag of reforms. It is clear that the Government's predominant view was that the establishment of a national scheme should have priority, and the breaking of new ground in the area of reform should wait for more considered legislation in a context in which the national Parliament will have the capacity so to legislate, because there will be a national legislative framework.

The three areas I particularly want to refer to, although not in any detail, are the areas of insider trading, insolvency and shield of the Crown. In all those areas action is under way-on insider trading, by the House of Representatives committee; on insolvency, in the consideration of the report previously brought down; and, on shield of the Crown, in the examination by the Senate Standing committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

For all those reasons, in this second reading debate, without dealing in detail with some of the amendments which will come up in the committee stage about which I may wish to make further detailed comment, I support the Bill. This Bill is a further step forward from the cooperative scheme, which in itself was a step forward. It reflects the structure of companies and the the nature of corporate activity, the changes within them, and the changes that seem reasonably likely to occur. As those changes take place corporate law needs to change, and this is an appropriate and timely reform. I support the package of legislation and look forward to its speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on what is certainly a very important package of legislation. Despite the fact that the Opposition disagrees with the ultimate position adopted by the Government in pursuing a national companies scheme, it is fair to say that the work undertaken by the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation was of great value in identifying a number of important areas for reform. Ultimately the effectiveness of that work in the daily commercial operations of the market will be a reflection of the very assiduous work undertaken by the members of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to commence by saying that I certainly appreciated the opportunity to serve on the Committee. I appreciated the cut and thrust of the many non-partisan discussions that Senator McMullan has mentioned. I certainly thought that between us we were able to identify a number of areas for improvement. However, in respect of the fundamental need for a national companies scheme, I think that a lot of propaganda has been put around to justify what I think is ultimately a quite dangerous course of events. One of the virtues of the cooperative scheme was that there was a diffusion of responsibility.

I noted that Senator McMullan talked about accountability, and I suppose that, in one sense, this could be a sophisticated rerun of arguments about centralism because, quite clearly, one wants to know where power resides. But, in an area as sensitive as this, where there is a great capacity for people to intervene, improperly at times, and where the stakes are enormously high, there are overwhelming temptations to bring political pressures to bear. We saw that in relation to the Rothwells matter where the Commonwealth Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, declined to intervene on the spurious basis that it was a matter for the Western Australian State Government-although he well knew that a State election was imminent and, of course, nothing was done until afterwards. We know also that, because the National Companies and Securities Commission does not have an office in Western Australia, its delegate was the local Corporate Affairs Commission, and that there were certainly instances of even the Chairman of the NCSC being prevailed upon not to disclose the name of Mr Laurie Connell, to approve the rescue package without publicising all the details, and in many ways, I think, to provide preferential treatment to one who would have been best brought undone much earlier. That should ring alarm bells for us because it means that we should be vigilant in the extreme. If there are virtues deriving from having a cooperative scheme with a diffusion of power and responsibility, then that may well be a very important safeguard. But what is proposed by the Government in this centralised scheme is effectively a concentration of power which will enable both the Attorney-General's Department and ultimately the Commonwealth Attorney-General to exercise what could well be unhealthy influence.

I noted that Senator McMullan and others have said that transparency now derives from the fact that one can require the tabling of a ministerial direction. But I am sure that we are all aware that influence can be brought to bear in many subtle ways, and certainly where it is possible for a Minister to give a formal direction it is equally possible for him to indicate in advance that that is his intention, and in such a situation it is not hard to envisage that people might well back off. Certainly, I think that is a matter for concern.

I think the way in which commercial settlements have been achieved in a number of instances leaves a lot to be desired. I am one who is less inclined to favour plea bargaining in this area. I think there is a very significant demonstration effect, and ultimately a deterrent, when corporate players know that the watchdog has the necessary powers and is prepared to exercise them. But if the NCSC is starved of funds and is under great pressure not to waste money on expensive litigation, the temptation for it to seek to achieve a so-called commercial settlement can often be at the expense of either a conviction or an investigation being taken to its proper conclusion. The Bell-Bond-State Government Insurance Corporation (SGIC) saga was probably the classic example of that. The difficulties were compounded by the fact that the shield of the Crown hovered like a sword of Damocles over all of the litigants and ultimately was able to be exercised to the benefit of not only the SGIC but also the Bond Corporation itself. I think one can say that there were very good grounds for suspecting that if the shield of the Crown had not been a factor, the NCSC may well have gone much further than its tentative view that Bond and the SGIC had been guilty of unacceptable conduct. Nonetheless, I think it is necessary to have that ultimate power to achieve a commercial settlement, and we should support the recommendation of the Committee that any obstacles that might inhibit that should be removed.

In respect of the panel system, I must say that, as I understand it, at present the Government is accepting the minority report which proposes that there be a separation between the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), as the investigator, and the panel as the adjudicator. As one with some legal training, I am very much aware of the need to achieve that separation of powers; it can indeed be an overwhelming temptation at times for an over-zealous prosecutor to seek to intimidate those whom the prosecutor believes have been guilty of some wrongdoing. In many ways it is a fundamentally important part of the legal process to have this separation of powers-to have a safety valve and not simply a regulator which is able to threaten that its preliminary view will be confirmed by itself unless certain action is taken.

The concept of natural justice is certainly very fashionable these days, but the essential ingredients of the principles of natural justice are that one has a right to be heard, and to be heard by a tribunal free of bias. It is very difficult, where the prosecutor is the judge and jury, for a litigant to get a fair hearing. I think there is a very real danger-although there is not very much evidence of it to date-that where the NCSC or its successor body is out to make its mark and where it believes there has been some reprehensible conduct, it will in effect use its powers in terrorem and will seek to achieve commercial settlements and various other arrangements that should not properly be its province but should ultimately be decided upon by an independent body such as the panel. For my part, I must say that I am still attracted to the virtues of a panel that is separate and distinct from the investigating body.

There was some considerable concern and constitutional doubt about the legitimacy of the Commonwealth approach. As time went by, the legal opinion of Sir Maurice Byers assumed the status of holy writ, and there were very few who were prepared seriously to take issue with it. In fact, it was very late in the day that the Committee received a submission from the Law Institute of Victoria which I thought raised some very serious doubts about matters which went to the heart of the opinion. For example, the question of whether a company is a trading corporation or a financial corporation needs to be determined on a case by case basis. Byers himself concedes that the ambit of `companies' would not extend to recreational, scientific, educational or charitable companies, and clearly there would be doubts surrounding listed companies which were merely holding companies. Similarly, there would be other unincorporated associations, building societies and friendly societies which would not be susceptible to even this extended definition of the corporations power. So the notion that somehow a national scheme will encompass all of these bodies is quite misguided. The fact is that there will continue to be a need for State legislation to regulate the activities of a whole range of corporate and semi-corporate bodies and, of course, there will need to be transitional arrangements to ensure that those that are properly amenable are dealt with fairly. There is a conspicuous absence in the legislation of any such transitional provisions.

As I think I said earlier, we have heard quite a deal of hyperbole. I recall Senator Macklin claiming that the principal justification for this national approach what that, as the Business Council of Australia would argue, it is unrealistic to have a cooperative scheme when we are aspiring to operate in an international business environment. In the evidence before us we did not come across any examples of Australian corporations that experienced difficulties in the international arena as a result of any failings in the cooperative scheme. Certainly Elders might complain about the United Kingdom Monopolies Commission or Bond might blame a range of other factors but no-one at any stage suggested that our ability to operate internationally is impeded by the form of companies and securities legislation in this country. So the minority on the Committee found talk of that type of internationalisation of the financial community as essentially sloganistic and misleading in this context. We all recognise the need to have an international and export-oriented approach, but that is not the same thing as saying that we need to have national companies legislation. In many ways that proposition is a red herring.

The second major argument that is often advanced to justify a national scheme is that it is necessary to have accountability to parliament and to ensure that there is direct responsibility for the action of regulators and others. The Committee did not have provided to it any examples of actual or proposed changes in Commonwealth power which were necessary in that regard. Indeed, I do not think one can really point to any examples of why parliaments currently are not fulfilling their role.

There are a number of constitutional traditionalists, I think, who express concerns that somehow the Parliament is being frozen out of the process, but I think that is a little precious. The primary concern should be whether the community at large is agitated about the speed of the process, about the accountability and administration of companies and securities law. We simply did not get any submissions that expressed concern on that basis. It was really a lawyer's point. I do not think that is sufficient reason for saying that somehow the ability of the Commonwealth is non-existent and that the States are rubber stamps. The Ministerial Council constitutes a diffusion of responsibility. If it wants to seek amendments to the legislation then it must bring them before both Commonwealth and State parliament. In that instance I think there is the capacity for legislative intervention and, ultimately, parliamentary supervision.

The notion of a joint standing committee on corporations is very valuable. It predates Senator Macklin's recommendation, as I recall it. I do not know whether it goes back to the Rae Committee, but I seem to have read about that suggestion some years back. Nonetheless, it was well picked up by Senator Macklin. It will go a long way towards allaying some of the concerns people might have about the way in which the Ministerial Council might have operated in the past or the way in which the Department or the Minister might operate in the future. There will be opportunities to voice concerns without too great a period of delay because, after all, time is often of the essence in these matters.

The third area of supposed justification for having a national scheme was that somehow there is currently administrative duplication and general inefficiency. I thought that concern was greatly overstated. The examples that were given to us were essentially trivial. Again, I could not see how it could be said that the efficient operations of companies and securities law in this country is currently impeded.

In this day and age, with fax machines able to operate around the world and certainly interstate, there is no reason why people cannot get all that they require from the State corporate affairs commissions. Certainly, with a computerisation of their corporate data bases there should not be any difficulties in obtaining all the information that might be required by way of company and business name searches. Again, I think that concern was overstated. Since these were, I thought, tendentious propositions that did not really address the way in which the system operates at the moment, taking the range of submissions into account I think one could say that by and large the system works pretty well.
I will say a few words about takeovers. I find myself in a minority of two with Senator McMullan in respect of the requirement for the prevetting of takeover documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were in a majority this morning.

—I presume that Senator Richardson is an expert in this field. It depends on what one regards as important. At the moment all we are concerned about is corporations. The discussion about the virtues or prevetting was very interesting. It is probably a classic case of the Government going to water. It has a number of analogies in the current drive for micro-economic reform where the Government holds itself out as the big deregulator but where all it is doing is reregulating. We will be debating the telecommunications Bill shortly-a classic example of setting up a structure that has all sorts of unnecessary licensing provisions and regulatory arrangements, all designed to protect Telecom's monopoly rather than to promote competition. I think it comes through again very much here.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's initial proposal was that there was no need for prevetting in relation to either prospectuses or takeover documents, simply because there is a capacity in others to do the work that is currently done by administrative officials. I ended up thinking that there was something to be said for an independent review of prospectus documents. Quite often there are fly by night operators who do not operate under the same constraints as publicly listed companies which might engage in takeover operations and which want to be around for the next game.

Prospectuses are in a slightly different position. People can make overblown claims in the hope of making a quick quid and disappearing. So there is a justification for retaining prevetting in that area, but when it comes to takeover documents the Government started out with the right approach, and that was that the target company is the one that is perfectly equipped to find fault with the part A statement. If it is motivated to dispute the matter it will take it to court. It should have the carriage of the action and it should decide the extent to which it wants to disagree with it. But there should ultimately be an ability in the regulator, in this instance, I suppose, the ASC, to intervene if necessary in the public interest. If minority shareholders' rights are not being protected then clearly there is a need for a watchdog to intervene.

But there is no need at all in my view for it to be necessary to have every document scrutinised. All that does is give lawyers a parachute ultimately to pass the buck but still charge vast amounts of money. I think that is unnecessary. It does not really add much to the process. It certainly slows matters down a bit because someone else has to plough through the document, and as with all bureaucrats there is often an irresistible temptation to justify one's existence by coming up with some matters that need attention. Ultimately, as I say, it is regrettable that the Government went to water on this issue because it involves a bit of intestinal fortitude to throw the matter open and to remove the shackles. Ultimately, I suppose the Government was afraid that one mistake might be made and someone would squeal that there should have been government supervision. That then becomes the justification for doing it in every instance. That is the height of inefficiency.

I will say a few more words on shield of the crown, which I think is still a very important issue. I am very pleased that Senator Cooney's committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, will be investigating it. In an era of increasingly commercial activities by government business enterprises it becomes imperative when they get into the marketplace and engage in takeovers, joint ventures and other commercial operations that they be subject to the same benefits and disbenefits as other players. That is manifestly not the case at present. The Government has a strange reluctance to do anything about it. Certainly the States have been paranoid about any suggestions of removing the shield and, hopefully, when the Senate Committee has had the opportunity to demonstrate why there does need to be reform in the area, the Government will be prepared to bite the bullet. But I am sure that it will have to be driven to do so.

Ultimately, therefore, I conclude by saying that I think there are quite a number of areas where sensible reform can be achieved, where an enhanced cooperative scheme can be made to work even better and to accommodate the concerns of not just State administrations but State corporations that have voiced very real objections. The opportunity was there for the Government to have accommodated all those concerns, but instead it chose to adopt this centralist approach. Whether it is a monument to the Attorney-General or simply a desire to accumulate more power in the hands of a Minister or a department we will never know, but the end result I think is one that is unnecessary. It may well throw up some very real concerns about concentration of power and influence. I think it is certainly unnecessary on the evidence before the Committee. I join with my Opposition colleagues in opposing the Government amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposals to establish a national companies and securities scheme I suppose go back 20 years or more. They really resulted from the fact that the company laws in Australia had traditionally been those of the States. Of course, there were a lot of differences between them. The first movement occurred in an endeavour to obtain-sometimes successfully-a uniform companies law. That coincided with the very major changes in securities markets in Australia. They were becoming far more national. When Australia was hit with a stock market boom at the end of the 1960s, a great many tensions evolved as a result of which the Senate set up the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange. The Committee took several years to investigate the stock markets, their operation and the adequacy of the laws of Australia, and that resulted in the recommendation for a national watchdog to sit above the existing administration of company and securities laws. Changes in the law were not finalised as a result of the defeat of the Whitlam Government. The Attorney-General introduced national companies law but that was never even debated in the Senate; it went off to a committee and the Government lost office before anything further was done.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the background to the establishment of the present regulation of companies, securities and stock markets known as the cooperative scheme. That scheme established the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), which is the national watchdog envisaged by the report of that Senate Committee. However, the scheme is a much more elaborate one than that because it sought to marry the attempts at uniform company law throughout Australia thereby obtaining the benefits of a national law, while leaving the major administration of company laws with the State governments, which had developed what was known then as companies offices but which I think are now called corporate affairs commissions. They sat, as I said, above them all, gaining more experience, with greater influence coming from the National Companies and Securities Commission.

For eight or nine years we have had a scheme in Australia for the regulation of companies, securities and stock markets that has worked, I believe, reasonably well. There has certainly been some criticisms of it and many have been misinformed. Some of the criticisms made by the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the proposals that he has now brought into this Parliament, and which we are debating in this Senate, are very strange indeed. The Attorney-General, referring in his second reading speech to the establishment of the present scheme, stated:
The then Federal Government-
that is, the Fraser Government-
was more intent on leaving State governments with control of companies and securities within their jurisdiction than it was with meeting the needs of the wider Australian community.

That is an entirely false and misleading statement about what the reasons for the cooperative scheme were. As I have already indicated, there is a long history of State regulation of companies and securities and of State laws on the subject. There was in place well experienced State administration, but there were certain deficiencies; namely there was not a national watchdog, and the scheme provided for that, and there were, and still are, very serious doubts as to whether the Commonwealth Parliament can cover the field of companies and securities law. To characterise what the Fraser Government did in this way I believe is not only offensive, but also quite untrue.

The Attorney-General has also endeavoured to make a case that the operation of the scheme has been deficient and that it has not been able to meet the challenges of recent years. I suppose he is referring to the very firm establishment of a national market which was clearly in place 20-odd years ago; it is not something that has happened in recent years. He also seems to have found some reason why Australia's markets are not able to satisfy the needs of its international position. That argument has been well and truly dealt with by the previous speaker, Senator Alston, and by the minority report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation which is also available for us to debate this evening. Certainly there is no evidence to suggest that Australia's regulation of companies and securities is in any way impeding the operation of our participation in the international markets in this arena, and that should be laid aside as a reason of any substance. It may be that it could be described as deficient in some respects but those deficiencies could be rectified within the current structure of the scheme. There was a rather amusing comment in the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who represents the Attorney-General in the Senate, where he said:
There has been community concern that markets have been manipulated.

If the Attorney-General believes that his scheme or any scheme will prevent some market manipulation, he has either a great deal of optimism or he has access to some greater wisdom than he reveals in anything he said or in the legislation he has brought forward. Certainly market manipulation was one longstanding problem in the period of which I have been speaking.

The National Companies and Securities Commission was set up to provide a national response by way of its investigatory powers that would result in prosecutions. That, of course, will be an ongoing problem. Indeed, it is one of the major reasons why there has been so much concern about the operation of the new Australian Securities Commission proposed by this legislation. There will always be problems in this area and we must have laws to deal with them.

The other argument of the Attorney-General seems to refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which in 1987 reported on the role of the Parliament in the national companies scheme. According to the Attorney-General, the Committee concluded that the scheme had outlived its usefulness. That was about the third Senate committee which had looked at these matters. It reported critically on the lack of what it perceived as ministerial accountability to this Parliament in respect of the cooperative scheme. As its name implies, that scheme set up a council comprising the Commonwealth Minister, whoever he happens to be-it is the Attorney-General at the moment; it has been other Ministers in the past-the State Ministers, and the Northern Territory Minister responsible for this area of the law. This ministerial council, the body which has the responsibility for the oversight of this scheme, is the body to which the National Companies and Securities Commission is responsible. It also is the body which recommends any changes in the law which are required. It does not administer the scheme in detail because that is done, as I have said, by the Corporate Affairs Commissions of the States. But it is certainly an unusual and unique form of providing accountability. The agreements which set the council up place an obligation on the Commonwealth Government to give effect to the decisions of the Ministerial Council in the form of legislation.

The only laws which are needed to amend the scheme are laws of this Parliament which are introduced after they have been approved by the Ministerial Council. As I said, this means that there is a grave weakening of ministerial responsibility under this scheme. Clearly there are problems associated with the question of ministerial responsibility and the power of Parliament in relation to it. In my view-it is a view which I have expressed on several occasions in recent years in this chamber-those problems are not in any way insurmountable. They certainly do not justify throwing out a scheme which has a great many benefits simply because it presents problems of this kind.

On 16 November 1983 I made a speech in the Senate on the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 which was one of the early Bills that were brought in. I think it was the first major Bill to amend in detail the scheme after various pieces of legislation had been passed over previous years to bring it into operation. The Minister in charge of that Bill said that, as all the amendments had been approved by the Ministerial Council following wide consultation, therefore this Parliament must pass it. He said that we could not amend it and that if we rejected it we would be rejecting the scheme.

That was an old standby that had been used by State Ministers when the uniform schemes were in operation. State parliaments were told that they could not really change in any way and certainly could not reject Bills to give effect to amendments to the uniform scheme. It is simply not true that that takes away the responsibility of this Parliament for passing the legislation. If the worst came to the worst and the Parliament amended it in a way which was unacceptable to the Ministerial Council or, indeed, rejected legislation proposed by it, that would not necessarily spell and end to the scheme. It undoubtedly would be a problem which would have to be faced. As I said in my speech on that occasion in the course of the committee stage of that Bill, the benefits of the scheme were so considerable that the States would certainly be most reluctant to abandon it simply because there was a difference of opinion between this Parliament and the Ministerial Council. I have no doubt that if faced with a situation like that further negotiations would occur in order to save this scheme and also give effect to at least some of the views of the Parliament.

Therefore, in essence I do not believe that this scheme necessarily involves, by any means, an abrogation of ministerial responsibility or the powers of Parliament. I put that aside as a good reason for abandon- ing the present scheme simply because it has difficulties in the way of the smooth operation of the principles of ministerial responsibility.

The great merit of the existing scheme is the doubt about the powers of this Parliament to cover the field. They are set out in the Constitution which gives the Parliament powers to make laws with respect to:
(xx) Foreign corporations, and trading or financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth:

It is well known that there are various forms of corporations which may not be trading corporations or financial corporations. Questions arise as to whether the Commonwealth's powers extend that far. Clearly holding companies have always been an example where there could be doubts as to the ambit of the Commonwealth's power. When one looks at the wording of this power of the Commonwealth, it refers to such corporations `formed within the limits of the Commonwealth'. There has always been a doubt as to whether that means that such corporations can in fact be formed by a Commonwealth law or whether they can apply only to those companies that have already been formed under some other law, whether a foreign law or a law of a State of Australia.

Sir Maurice Byers, on whom the Government relies so solidly and who impressed so much the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, believes that the High Court of Australia would overcome those difficulties. But he has indicated that there are some areas that would not be able to be covered, namely, companies which were formed for recreational purposes, or scientific, educational or charitable purposes. Sir Maurice Byers recognises that the constitutional power is deficient at least to that extent.
