TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was referring to the doubts and problems that arise under Commonwealth power in relation to this area. Those doubts were fundamental to the decision to enter into the cooperative scheme. To recapitulate in that regard, I point out that the cooperative scheme provided constitutional certainty about its operation. That has never been challenged and it is unlikely it ever would be challenged because it was very carefully planned to cope with this fundamental problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme has enabled all the powers of the Commonwealth and the States to be utilised. In that regard, it has provided a certain basis for the scheme and has also delivered a uniform law. That uniform law has been able not only to sweep up the traditional areas of companies and securities, but also to bring within its ambit a whole lot of matters which are described in legal jargon as `prescribed interests', which I do not intend to go into. A good example of that is the futures industry. Futures interests, whatever they may be, are certainly not shares in companies. They cannot be brought within that concept of company law. They have now been brought under the cooperative scheme because of the growth of futures markets, both national and international. Attempts are being made to bring them under this new scheme; they may succeed. At least it can be said they have to be brought under this present scheme in an artificial way.

Under the existing cooperative scheme there has been certainty, a most important consideration-perhaps the most important consideration for the business community. It is very interesting to note that despite initial support by the business community for the concept of this national scheme, business interests and their professional advisers deserted the scheme in droves once they realised uncertainty would be created. I do not have time to quote the number of people who have commented on this. Probably the most telling remarks of all are those put forward by Mr John Green, a Sydney corporate lawyer. His views are quoted in the dissenting report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. On page 200 of the report of the Committee he is quoted as saying:

If I can deal first with the Bowen plan, I must say that I regret that his radical, but I believe well conceived, plan for Australia's corporate regulation has gone off the rails . . . If the Bowen plan means that the new federal laws are brought in with State opposition I would, I must say, withdraw my support for it . . . If some sensible compromise is not reached between the Commonwealth and the States and the Bowen plan becomes law I fear that corporate Australia will be besieged by what I believe will be an era of greater uncertainty.

In addition to the benefits that I have mentioned, the cooperative scheme has provided in the National Companies and Securities Commission a most invaluable corporate watchdog. It was established under the leadership of a very distinguished Australian, a lawyer of the highest ethical and legal standing in Melbourne, Mr Leigh Masel, who gave it a magnificent start. The standards he set have been followed under the leadership of Mr Bosch. Although the NCSC may have made a slow start and lots of legal problems had to be overcome in such a field, as time has gone on it has certainly developed greater expertise and authority. The NCSC is now widely accepted in Australia as a body which can be trusted as the national corporate watchdog and one which can tackle those manifold problems that have been presented.

The fourth benefit delivered by the co- operative scheme was decentralised administration. All the proponents of national laws on this subject seem to overlook the fact that the vast majority of companies in Australia are small, mostly private companies, which operate within one State. They are not national companies. There is a very great distinction indeed between the national market in which the big players operate and that in which the small companies operate. Despite the so-called limitations of the cooperative scheme, big companies are operating more and more in international markets. Overwhelmingly, company law administration is dealing with small companies. We do not want national administration for this vast majority of companies in Australia; we do not want them to have to deal with the administrative minutiae that are involved in that exercise. The existing scheme is very well suited to decentralised administration; I fear that decentralised administration will be lost under a national scheme.

Coming back to the question of the national markets, I point out that under the existing scheme the best possible proof of the way in which it has developed as a national body is the fact that in recent years the stock exchanges of Australia have themselves formed a national stock exchange. In recent years, the face of the stockmarket in Australia has changed out of all recognition. It has done so under the aegis of the existing scheme. That is the picture that we have. Then we have this legislation foisting this scheme on the Australian business community and the large numbers of people who are concerned with its successful operations.

There will be legal uncertainty and constitutional challenges which may or may not clarify the situation. A test case will have to be set up early because the States will not lie down and accept this scheme just because it has been passed by this Parliament. Even if we can have some test case, which will be very difficult to mount, there will still be constitutional uncertainties and areas which cannot be controlled by this Parliament, as Sir Maurice Byers himself has pointed out. Therefore, there will always be the need for some State laws in this area. There will be a need for cooperation between the Commonwealth and the States, no matter how wide the High Court may grant Commonwealth power, and that is very much in doubt.

Without continuing the NCSC, the Government is to set up a new Australian Securities Commission which is to be not only a national watchdog, but also the one national regulatory body. It will do all the work that has been done by the NCSC and the State Corporate Affairs Commissions. If it succeeds-and it has the power to-it will be concerned with all that administrative detail. It will not provide decentralised administration, even if the States were cooperative which, by all accounts, they will not be. The Government will have only the same sort of decentralised administration it has under other purely Commonwealth bodies such as the Australian Taxation Office, the Social Security Appeals Tribunals and so on. We will lose that great benefit that the existing scheme has had in decentralised administration. That is really what the State issue is about. It is not about money-the Commonwealth has already offered them monetary compensation, but they still have not been bought off. They have not been bought off because they are responding to their own constituents who want to have ready access, in their own cities, to advice. They want ready access to the negotiating position the professional advisers are able to give in the administration of this area.

Finally, I come back to the question of ministerial responsibility. Although, as I have admitted, there are some difficulties about that, they can largely be overcome-in the first place, by the establishment of the parliamentary committee. That notable recommendation of the Joint Committee has been accepted by the Government. I am very pleased about that, and I congratulate the Government. It is something that I have advocated in the Senate since 1983, and it has been adopted by the Opposition as policy since 1984. A very important way of overcoming the difficulty in the existing scheme would be to have a parliamentary body which would become expert in this area, and to which the Ministerial Council would ultimately have to justify its recommendations for new laws. Another way in which the difficulties could be overcome would be for the Commonwealth to assume the permanent chairmanship of the Ministerial Council. I am sure that the States would be prepared to agree to that.

So there are ways of overcoming the difficulties in the present scheme. In my view-and I am pleased that the view of the Opposition is the same-it is far better to overcome the difficulties and deficiencies in the present scheme that can be overcome than to embark upon the very grave doubts, indeed the lottery, that we would be embarking upon if Parliament were to agree to this new scheme. For those reasons I am opposed to the legislation, and I trust the Senate will reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's opposition to this package of Corporations Bills is based on its view that they are not constitutionally viable. I understand that the Opposition is happy with the rest of the issues that are before the Senate. In other words, the general thrust of the legislation, so far as the Opposition is concerned, is good. Honourable senators opposite say simply that it should be left to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, that the Ministerial Council has all the wisdom in the world, that there is nothing wrong with it, that it is a group of reasonable men and women who go round interested in only one thing: cooperation and getting ahead with administering the corporate sector of this community-a most important sector indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: It was all very interesting when the Senate Select Committee on Corporations Legislation that looked into this Bill was going round Australia and talking to all sorts of people. It was accompanied by Mr Brian O'Callaghan, who is in the chamber at the moment. He gave the Committee considerable help. We discussed the issue of cooperation with various Attorneys-General. During those discussions the Attorney-General for South Australia, Mr Sumner, and the Attorney-General for Victoria, Mr McCutcheon, said that the cooperative system could be, and should be, maintained on the basis of more power being given to the Commonwealth, and that if the Commonwealth could not come to an agreement with the States on such issues as mergers and takeovers, the Commonwealth would prevail-but only after discussions with the general Ministerial Council. That seemed a very reasonable proposition. Indeed, some of us on the Committee thought that perhaps it was the way we ought to go. If we had had Senator Durack's assurance that all these men-I think that they are all men-are reasonable people, perhaps that is the way we could have gone.

But what happened? When this suggestion was put to the Attorney-General of New South Wales he moved back several feet, metaphorically speaking, and said, `No, we can't have that sort of movement'. Anyone looking at the track record on this issue will see that the sorts of agreements that one might want for a perfect, or near perfect, system are lacking, and one does not get the sort of agreement that has been lauded so much today by honourable senators opposite.

This reminds me very much of how the Co-operative Scheme Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 comes before us. It is a very thick Bill indeed, going to 160 pages. Of course, legislation which should have been passed long ago was forthcoming only when the threat of Federal legislation was seen. In other words, the Co-operative Scheme Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 finds its way into this chamber in the context of the Commonwealth wanting to move and, as I will indicate later, move properly to bring some better sense and some better effect to the law governing corporations in this country.

Let us look at what has happened with the Ministerial Council and at what happens with the States. There is reason for concern that the cooperative scheme would not have worked as well as it has been suggested today it would have worked in the past. Indeed, when the Senate Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs considered the role of parliament in relation to national companies schemes, that Committee, which began its work in 1986, was very ably-indeed brilliantly-chaired by Senator Michael Tate and then by Senator Bolkus. It had before it evidence about the cooperative scheme. Criticism of the cooperative scheme came from the then chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange Ltd, Mr Ian Roach, who said this:
There is only one market for securities in Australia and it is part of the global market . . . it is essential that we pool our resources and one united stock exchange . . .
Indeed, that has happened: there is one stock exchange in Australia, operating in all States. Mr Henry Bosch, Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), had this to say:

1985-86 saw a number of striking developments. Perhaps the most remarkable were the steps towards the internationalisation of the financial community. Links between stock markets and futures markets were created and strengthened, Australian shares and financial instruments were traded in increasing volumes on foreign markets. Many financial institutions established or developed branches or connexions overseas. Flows of information and funds have become almost instantaneous and financial markets are becoming increasing interdependent.
Mr Robert Gardini, who represented the Confederation of Australian Industry, tabled letters before the Committee. One of those commented:
It would be accepted that the regulation of companies whose business transcends State borders can only be satisfactorily achieved through Commonwealth legislation . . .

There are other quotes to that effect. The reality is that times have moved, technology has moved, and the stock market has moved. It is now not only national but international, and it is proper that the Government which represents Australia in the international field-the Commonwealth Government-has the carriage of the legislation which will affect the law governing corporations. Indeed, that is hardly a new idea. The Opposition has come into this chamber and said, `Look, this mad move towards Commonwealth legislation is all revolutionary'. What is the situation? One should go back to the National Australasian Convention debates, between the founding fathers, which took place in Sydney from 2 March to 9 April 1891 and look at the contribution by Mr Munro on 3 April 1891. When talking about the suggested words to be put into the Constitution, which read `the status in the Commonwealth of foreign corporations and of corporations formed in any State or part of the Commonwealth', he said this:

We have agreed to subclause 13, dealing with the incorporation of banks, and I do not see why a similar provision should not be made in regard to the incorporation of companies. Why should they not be under control of federal offices? At the present time the law as to incorporation is different in different colonies, and the result is extremely unsatisfactory in many cases. I do not see why we should not make the same provision in regard to the incorporation of companies as we have made in regard to the incorporation of banks.

That statement was made 98 years ago. Unfortunately, the Opposition seems to be living back then-or even before then, because if it had been living 98 years ago it would have seen the merit of Mr Munro's statements. So it must have been living at a time prior to that; well over 100 years ago. Sir Samuel Griffith, a great jurist, cavilled at that a bit. He said he did not think that the suggestion put forward by the previous speaker, Mr Munro, should be accepted in its full sense. He said:

I do not think we should. There are a great number of different corporations. For instance, there are municipal, trading, and charitable corporations, and these are all incorporated in different ways according to the law obtaining in the different states.
He said:
What is important, however, is that there should be a uniform law for the recognition of corporations.
Sir John Bray went on in the same debate to say:

If it is desirable to entrust legislation as to the incorporation of banks to the federal government, there is no reason why we should not say that the registration of financial companies doing all the business of banks should be dealt with in the same manner.

There are a few things arising out of that. One is that it was certainly in the thoughts of the founding fathers of the Commonwealth that companies should be dealt with. They certainly expressed the desire 98 years ago that there should be uniform laws. The period of 98 years since then has shown more and more just how sensible our founding fathers were. However, when an attempt is made to incorporate into the legislation a Bill which will solve the problems they were talking about then there is great opposition. As I understand the Opposition's proposition, it is really that this Bill has been put forward, as Senator Short has said, for the sole reason of giving some sort of memorial to the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen.

TALK.START.PARA: —He tried with the referendum.

—Senator Bishop has now given away the approach the Opposition takes in relation to this. She has said, `Mr Lionel Bowen brought forward some referendum Bills simply to make himself a monument. We have defeated them. Since we won on that occasion, we will oppose this Bill'. That is the rationale of the Opposition to this Bill, as I understand it.
—Is she front bench material?
—I think she is. Given the quality of the material on the Opposition benches, Senator Bronwyn Bishop is more than front bench material. She is leadership material.
—Prime ministerial material.
—Prime ministerial material.
—Senator Cooney, might I beg your indulgence to pass your remarks through the Chair.

—I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President, with great sincerity. I unintentionally strayed from what I should have been saying. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, let me say it seems to me to be extraordinary that the Opposition opposes this Bill because it had a big win, as it sees it, on the referendum Bills and now it wants a big win on this. I would have thought that there would have been a more highly elevated reason for opposing this measure-perhaps the claim that State rights should be protected, or some other basis. But certainly there should be a higher basis for opposing this Bill than simply that the Opposition has had a win on the referendum Bills and could possibly score another win here. While I am on the subject of the Attorney-General, this is his last session in this Parliament. He has been subject to some criticism. In my view, he has adorned the office. I think he has struggled with great endeavour.
—Did you say he adorned the office?
—Yes, adorned the office.
—He achieved nothing. He was hanging on the wall, was he?

—I will tell the Senate why he has adorned the office. He has struggled hard to bring about much-needed reform in this country. Let me explain that. A country moves with its history and history produces needs as it goes along. Great governments and great Ministers seek to meet those needs. The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has seen the needs-and his vision will be borne out as time goes by-and has moved to meet them. I have no doubt that if this package of Bills is defeated, similar ones will be back before this Parliament within a fairly short span of years. They will go through unanimously, because with the development of world trade, with the development of electronic gadgetry, with the need for laws to be made quickly and to be changed quickly at times, there is a need for a decisive government to be at the centre of these things and the Federal Government is the appropriate one for that.

SPEECH.PARA: There is much talks about the difficulty to be faced before the High Court of Australia. People say, `Look, because there might be a challenge to the High Court, we ought to abandon any scheme to regulate companies properly'. If that were the situation, we may as well give the federal system away. We ought to at least have a centralised government or go back to six or seven separate countries, or colonies. Of course there will be disputes before the High Court. That is exactly what the founding fathers envisaged. That is why they set up chapter 3 of the Constitution. That is why they set up a system of law. That is why they set up the judicature. That is why the Judiciary Act has been passed, to provide a mechanism whereby the issues arising between States and between the States and the Commonwealth can be resolved. After all, it is not the most frightful thing in the world to go before the High Court. If one went up to the library and saw the number of volumes that learned judges have filled over the years, one would see that many a person and many a government on many an occasion have gone before the High Court and come out alive. Therefore, to simply say that there are going to be High Court challenges seems not to meet the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's uncertain.

—Somebody has said it will leave a great deal of uncertainty in the breasts of companies. That may or may not be the situation, but the reality is that if a better system is to be achieved, it has to be done through a scheme such as this. If a period of gestation is needed while the process is being worked out, so be it.
—It was very painful to give birth to that one.

—Of course it would be difficult to give physical birth to a statute and its commentaries of that size. But size is not what counts. Whether it is a Commonwealth or a cooperative scheme, there will still be the same amount of paper to carry around. The Commonwealth scheme is in volume 1 of the CCH and, of course, CCH has published more than one volume on company law. We have to go beyond the fact that this legislation is an alleged monument to the Attorney-General and that it is big. No matter what happens, the legislation will be big and we must get down to the question of who is to run the scheme. It may be a tremendous idea to have a parliamentary committee to oversee the future development of company law, but what effect will a parliamentary committee have on the Ministerial Council? We can have either a Ministerial Council and no effective parliamentary committee or an effective parliamentary committee with the legislation on companies being put through one parliament, namely, the Federal Parliament. It would have been a more democratic way of going about things to have it before the Federal Parliament because in reality, with the corporate scheme, there is no way that any parliamentarian-and we are all parliamentarians here except Senator Tate, who is a member of the Executive and likely to remain so for a long time-will have a say. If Senator Bishop wants to have a say in this legislation as a parliamentarian, she had best vote for this Bill because she will not get that ability through the cooperative scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The founding fathers contemplated that the Commonwealth would play a central role in company law. Later there was a decision of the High Court of Australia at the time of the reserve powers doctrine which unfortunately put back the development of this area for some time until the Rocla Pipes case in which the High Court repudiated what had gone before and helped lead on to the present situation. In my view, the legislation is worthy of passage through this Parliament. It should be passed. The difficulties that arise in terms of uncertainty or in terms of disputes that have to be resolved by the High Court become peripheral when balanced against what will be gained. The central point is that we will have very good legislation to help the corporate sector develop along with Australia's economic development in future. If we are to be a vibrant and vigorous economic entity we need a vibrant and vigorous corporate sector, and we are more likely to have that and have it in greater abundance under this scheme than under the cooperative scheme.

I now turn to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legis- lation and to the setting up of a panel which will have the power to make declarations of unacceptable conduct. At present that is done by the NCSC. Under the Bill, the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) will have the ability to collect evidence and having collected it to put it before the panel. The majority of the Committee, on a casting vote, said that the ASC should also have the ability, in addition to collecting evidence the panel and to its other powers, to make declarations. I heard Senator Alston speak on this subject and I agree with him that matters of propriety, civil liberties and tradition require that the investigative and the prosecuting functions be separated out from the judging function. It is appropriate that I quote the Vice-Chancellor, Sir Knight Bruce, in Pearse v. Pearse when he said:
Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely-may be pursued too keenly, may cost too much.
The submission made, I think by the NCSC, that the proposed ASC should have the power to make a declaration failed to take note of the warning given by the Vice-Chancellor on that occasion.

I say finally that a good deal of the material that is in the Bill came from the report of the Senate Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It is good to see that recommendations from reports by parliamentary committees do at times find their way into legislation. Some of the recommendations were: the use of plain English, and there has been an attempt to do that in this Bill; that comprehensive Commonwealth legislation be enacted and that has happened; and that the administration of company law be looked at, and that has also been done in the Bill.

I reiterate that this Bill ought to be passed. If it is not passed now it certainly will be passed in similar form in the future. As I understand the Opposition's approach, the constitutional power is its one major objection to the legislation. If it were constitutional and if it were appropriate for the Commonwealth to administer it, it would, in the opinion of the Opposition, be good legislation. All that is stopping its passage is this very timid approach to constitutional power. In those circumstances, it is a pity that a little more courage could not be shown to allow this very important legislation to be enacted so that the economy of this country and the administration of the corporate sector which is so essential to it could go from strength to strength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In his final words, Senator Cooney said that it was all a matter of lack of courage to seize the constitutional issues and to run with them as the Government is purporting to do. The fact is that it is not a matter of courage but a matter of principle, and the Opposition is opposed in principle to the seizing of centralised power in the corporations area to the detriment of the operations of business in the States. Let us look at the history of how this great pile of documents was born-some 3,000 pages to be digested, interpreted and argued before the courts over a long period of years before they have any final and definitive meaning. Senator Cooney said that he wanted a vibrant and vigorous business section. He will not get a vibrant and vigorous business section if it is laden down with many legal problems. Despite the fact that they may well be said to be a growth industry for the lawyers, these Bills certainly do not assist in making business vibrant and vigorous.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, let us take a look at the history of what this huge pile of paper, which looks as though forests may have died for it, has gone through. First of all, it was introduced into the other place on the last sitting day of the autumn session last year. It is the largest piece of legislation ever to come into Parliament since Federation. As I said before, there are some 3,000 pages. Debate occurred in the other place on 28 September last year. The Government introduced 280 amendments. The Opposition received a copy of those only the night before. It was then necessary to refer the matter to a committee to sort out the mess, and that committee's report was tabled last month. Consultation with the business sector has been deplorable. Indeed, after those 280 amendments went through the House of Representatives, the Government refused to reprint the amended Bills because it would have cost $40,000 to do so. So, this highly complicated legislation was left in an amended and bitty state to be dealt with-even consumed-by the business community.

This week, all of a sudden, the legislation is back in the Senate. This time there are another 87 amendments, which we received only in the last two days. Does that augur well for a good understanding and digesting of what is in these enormous tomes? What is the thrust behind the urgency for these Bills to present themselves, as a matter of some haste, in this chamber for debate again? It certainly does seem that it is part of this Government's own secret agenda to centralise power more and more.

I mentioned the referendums by way of interjection for two reasons. First was the thrust of the referendums-which, again, would have centralised power in Canberra-and, second, these Bills come with the same aim. Certainly the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) would have liked to have left this place with these Bills as his memorial, saying, `These are the great achievements that I have introduced and been successful in getting through the place.' Not so, and not to be so. The referendums, finally, after real grassroots politicking, were rejected outright by the electorate. It was the most massive defeat of any referendums in Australia's history.

Of course, these Bills are relevant to the referendums for another reason which is that the main opinion that was relied upon by the Government in pushing its referendums case was that of Sir Maurice Byers. The Bills before this chamber tonight are here very much as a result of an opinion of Sir Maurice Byers. Sir Maurice has been a distinguished lawyer. He has now entered into the political arena. He is now acting as a politician, no longer as the lawyer. During one of the referendums debates that went on for some time the Attorney-General, when we were discussing the defence of government schools (DOGS) case said, `Let us hear from Sir Maurice Byers. He knows all about that, and the definite way that the High Court may or may not interpret that.' I said, `But, of course, Sir Maurice has been known to be wrong.' Gough Whitlam said, `Name me a case.' So I did. He said, `That is only one case. Name me another.' So I did. Those cases were the Collector of Customs v. Brian Lawlov Automotives Pty Ltd, and Clunies-Ross v. the Commonwealth. On each occasion, we see that the Government has chosen to rely on the opinion of a well-respected lawyer; but, like all other lawyers, he is right only sometimes.

The referendums having failed, we now see these Bills back on the table. Little does it matter to the Government that all State and Territory governments oppose these Bills. Little does it matter to the Government that it could only find a single, big business voice to give it any backing, and that was in the early stages. The majority of people in the business sector reject the Bills outright. The Law Council of Australia rejected the legislation outright and said very simply:

The Law Council supports the principle of uniformity of law and administration in this field, but it is concerned about certain aspects of the present proposals. A basic concern is the doubt that exists as to the constitutional power of the Commonwealth to cover all the classes of corporations that need to be covered.
It stated later:
Some corporations which are at present governed by the State Acts will fall outside those categories.
Even if the powers are upheld. It continues:

This means that there will continue to be a need for State legislation to deal with those corporations. The prospect of co-existing Commonwealth and State legislation on corporations is a daunting one.

Of course, there would need to be many cases fought before the courts before any certainty of meaning was achieved. The letter from the Law Council that was put out at the end of the last year went on to say:

. . . it would be irresponsible for the Commonwealth to legislate on the basis of its existing constitutional powers. The Commonwealth should not legislate unless and until the Constitution has been appropriately amended, for example, in the manner recommended by the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission at page 137 of its report ``Trade and National Economic Management''.

Was that one of the referendum proposals that this Government sought to put before the people? Certainly not! Why not? If the constitutional powers that it purports to rely upon fail, how does the Government think that it will still get this package through? There is a way, of course. If one looks at the way in which these Bills have been couched, one will find that should the heads of power that it purports to rely upon fail, of course, there is always the external affairs power. Should we have the necessary agreement between New Zealand and Australia, following up the harmonisation of regulations between the two countries pursuant to closer economic relations, and we have a treaty, guess what? These Bills could come in under that head of power. The Government has quite deliberately taken the route of being prepared to test the corporations power, and other powers set out in section 51, but in the event that that fails there is always the external affairs power. How typical of this Government to find this power which is so convenient to circumvent the Constitution itself.

It is important to consider what the implications for the States and Territories are and how they perceive those to be. First of all, there is a loss of ability to influence policy. That would be a plus for a centralist government, but it is not a plus for those who believe in federalism. There would be a loss of ability to promote local business development. If I might return to those referendums, when I traverse the States of Australia, particularly Western Australia, I understand the hostility felt towards those dreaded people who live in the east, particularly those who live in Canberra. I understand also the sense of frustration that people feel that their individual rights to carry on business in their States is being directed by a bunch of people whom they never see.

Similarly, possible Commonwealth control of statutory or government corporations as well as credit unions and building societies is a concern for the States themselves. The States were so concerned that they sought a joint opinion from the Solicitors-General to comment on the scope of the Commonwealth power relied upon and to point out the difficulties, as their best legal advice could do, which would mean an impediment to the passage of these Bills. They did not deal with the external affairs power because at that stage it had not become evident that that was a reality.

According to the opinion of the State and Territory Solicitors-General, the following three points were important: firstly, the Commonwealth clearly cannot rely upon its corporations power to legislate in respect of corporations which are not trading or financial corporations; secondly, there is doubt as to whether the Commonwealth can rely upon its corporations power to legislate with respect to the non-business activities of trading or financial corporations; and, thirdly, those parts of the existing scheme relating to incorporation, internal regulation and trading in company shares are probably not within the Commonwealth's power.

There were also doubts as to the applicability of the Commonwealth's power to prescribe interest schemes, trusts, non-trading holding companies, and for the regulation of certain parts of the securities and futures industries. The Solicitors-General believe that no scheme could operate effectively which did not cover the interrelated matter of incorporation, internal regulation and trading in company shares. The Solicitors-General believe that there is a reasonable prospect that the High Court will conclude that the corporations power of the Commonwealth does not and should not extend to these matters, and that a dual regulatory system would need to be set up in each jurisdiction with the State or Territory concerned enacting complementary legislation and establishing administrative structures. As I said, the opinion that does not agree with that of the Solicitor-General is that of Sir Maurice Byers, QC.

Mr Gerry Peacocke, who is the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Greiner Government in New South Wales, said in a speech dealing with this question at the end of last year that he believed the issues dealing with this matter fell into four categories. Firstly, there were the political concerns; secondly, the legal aspects; thirdly, the implications for the States; and, fourthly, the reform proposals for the cooperative scheme. On those political realities he said:

As has most often been the case when the Hawke Government wants reform, it has been initiated from within the Government to meet its own agenda rather than overcoming any real problem which may exist as a result of the operation of the current system.

The simple reality is that this legislation is, again, Government driven. It is not designed to meet a need as perceived by the business sector, but rather to meet the Government's own internal agenda. The Liberal Party, in its policy, has said that it supports very strongly the cooperative scheme as it exists, but notes, of course, that it has impediments; that there is need for reform. Not only does it acknowledge that but it has definite policies to deal with it-but in consultation with the States. I return to Mr Peacocke's address. Mr Peacocke set out very strongly the opinion of the Solicitors-General, as I set out a little earlier, and said further that they were concerned that the High Court was becoming increasingly centralist in its philosophy and is more likely to permit the Commonwealth to take over most of the companies and securities field now than it was in the 1970s.

Fairly recently in this place we had a conference on regulations and ordinances-dealing with delegated legislation. In a most erudite paper that was given at that conference there was quite a deal of discussion dealing with the lawmaking powers of the High Court and its tendency to become more radical in the exercise of that function.

From a States point of view, areas in which it is believed improvements could be made to the current scheme include: the introduction of procedures to enable the Commonwealth to play a larger role in the formation and amendment of legislation; the appointment of the Commonwealth Attorney-General as the permanent Chairman of the Ministerial Council and to make the National Companies and Securities Commission directly responsible to him; the establishment of a management committee, comprising the heads of the State and Territory commissions and representatives of the NCSC and the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department, collectively to determine, for the approval of the Ministerial Council, the respective roles of the NCSC and its delegates; and common objectives and strategies for the scheme as well as issues such as priority allocation and resource utilisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you back that, Senator?
—There are many ways--
—I would like to know what you think.

—I am expressing a point of view put by one of the State governments. From our point of view, we say that we wish to consult further with the States to find ways in which we could make the current cooperative scheme work efficiently. Our fundamental decisions, and one with which I certainly agree, is that the current scheme, which has many of its aspects settled, known and certain, is by far the preferable route to travel than the adoption of this enormous set of proposals encompassed in the legislation before us. I quoted earlier from Mr Peacocke. I think his conclusion in the address I mentioned earlier is one with which I would agree. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The spectre of a wholly national companies scheme is of fundamental importance and consequence to business in this country. It is of fundamental importance to our economy and it is of fundamental importance to everyone in this country. But what is fundamentally of equal importance is the fact that a successfully operating and fair cooperative system contains the checks and balances necessary to protect us all from the excessive-and often absolute-power of central government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing a package of Bills, and the key aspect of this package, of course, is the Australian Securities Commission Bill. We in the Opposition oppose this Bill because it is unnecessary and, of course, unwanted. It destroys an effective, federalist, cooperative scheme for no good purpose except to advance the centralist ideology of the Australian Labor Party and provide an ego trip for a fading politician. It is well understood that, as many of my colleagues have said in this debate, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), before he retires from Parliament, wants to leave some legislative memorial behind him. Of course, this is his final attempt, as he was none too successful, as we all know, in changing the Constitution in last year's referenda. Given the expense of that exercise, and the far greater damage that this Bill would do to the business regulation in Australia, we would all do better to build him a statue beside Lake Burley Griffin or something of that nature, because it would be a darned site cheaper to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is not wanted by the State governments, which were not properly consulted prior to its introduction but, of course, that begs the question: Who was? Of course, the second reading speech to this Bill really reflects what this Government feels about State governments. I quote from that speech:

The then Federal Government was more intent on leaving State Governments with control of companies and securities within their jurisdiction than it was with meeting the needs of the wider Australian community.

The Minister says that rather derogatorily of previous coalition governments, and how dreadful it would be to have State rights. As we all know, that is what this is partly about. The Labor Attorney-General of South Australia has affirmed support for the uniformity achieved under the present federalist scheme and has supported the opposition of the local business community to this new scheme. The New South Wales Consumer Affairs Minister has spoken of `the need in a democratic country for checks and balances in all that we do'-despite any supposed advantages that larger States might expect to gain from centralisation.

This Bill has absolutely no support whatsoever in my State of Western Australia among business and professional groups. It is opposed by the Western Australian Branches of the Institute of Directors and the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Law Society of Western Australia, the Confederation of Western Australian Industry, the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia, the Western Australian Council of Trustee Companies Association and the Perth members of the stock exchange. I do not think there could possibly be a more comprehensive list of those who are opposed to this Bill and yet once again we see tonight, as we see so often, that no Western Australian Labor senators are supporting their constituents in this proposal. The more detail that has emerged regarding this legislation, the less support it has received. But this Government simply does not want to know about that.

Recently the Government has attempted to bulldoze this legislation through the Senate because it does not want the public to be made aware of what it is trying to do yet again. Last July the Confederation of Australian Industry-the ultimate representative, I might add, of 100,000 Australian businesses-withdrew its earlier support and informed the recent committee of inquiry that reform should be effected within the current structure. But that has also been ignored by this Government. It is only the representatives of the big corporations who have supported a Federal Government takeover. It is the very large firms that have the resources to deal directly with the Federal Government bureaucracy. Once more we have a clear example of this Labor Government caring only for the major firms. Leaping into bed with big business and the unions is the daily practice. Australians, unfortunately, are learning the hard way that there is a big difference between a government that is pro-business enterprise and one that is corporatist.

There is an excellent rule of thumb, which fortunately for those in the Government is disregarded by the Labor Party, that unless it is necessary to change, it is necessary not to change. The Hawke Labor Government must prove that the cooperative scheme for the regulation of companies and securities in place since 1979 has somehow failed and needs to be replaced. The reasons advanced have all been shown to be spurious and misleading. The Government has done nothing to show that there is any change needed or requested.

It is claimed that a centralised scheme is essential to enable Australia to compete in an international arena. The Government, however, consistently fails to point to any firm that has been disadvantaged in any way in its international dealings on account of the current scheme. It simply cannot give chapter and verse as to any of the practical difficulties that are purported to be inherent in this legislation. It is a falsehood to talk about the need for a national scheme of regulation as a euphemism for a Federal takeover. There could be nothing more truly national than the regulation of business law through a ministerial council of all Australian parliaments.

The question of accountability is another notable red herring, with the Ministerial Council being supposedly less answerable to the Parliament. In effect, according to this reasoning, the cooperative system is wrong because it restricts the ability of the Federal Parliament to amend it. Again, we have to ask what necessary changes have been frustrated. No necessary changes have been frustrated. That, yet again, is a figment of the imagination of this Labor Government. It is also highly likely that this Parliament could so legislate, just as it is the right of any State to withdraw from the scheme. Rather, evidence is increasing that the diffusion of power for present regulation is positively healthy.

It is highly unlikely that the Ministerial Council will ever reflect the views of only one side of politics. The system provides a guarantee against ill-conceived change made for party political reasons so that company law would be subject to passing political whims. How easy it would be for this, or any other Labor government for that matter, to pass anti-business legislation to keep the Left of the Australian Council of Trade Unions happy. How the Australian Democrats would love to further their insane hatred of our major corporations through legislative grandstanding. I think it is a great shame that in this day and age we are seeing political parties that are simply so narrow-minded that they will not concede that what they are attempting to do is wrong and unnecessary.

In recent months we had a taste of likely political manipulation of the regulatory system by this Labor Government when the Attorney-General himself failed to exercise his power to order a special investigation of the Rothwells Ltd collapse prior to the Western Australian State election. If that is not party political intervention of the highest order, what is? Were it not for the need to proceed in agreement with the Ministerial Council we might wonder if any information would have seen the light of day. Only last week we saw the interim report on Rothwells showing what a disaster that whole episode has been and how much the Western Australian Labor Government had been involved in spending taxpayers' money. A single government and parliament simply cannot be trusted to have full control of the regulation of business in Australia.

The third argument for change is the allegation that the federalist system produces administrative duplication and inefficiency. This is a well tried criticism of any federal institutional system. However, unfortunately for the critics we still live under a federal system, with the express approval of the voting public. If the Government needs to be reminded of that, it should think back only as far as last year.

The only major criticism of current arrangements is being rectified by the computerisation of the public corporate database. Indeed, the 1987 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that recommended change admitted that `the scheme performs remarkably well'. In 1989 the Labor Government is saying that the scheme no longer works remarkably well, but it has failed to explain either to us in the Parliament or to the electorate why it is no longer working remarkably well. In any case, clause 102 (4) (c) allows for the local administration of legislation so that in a purely administrative sense there may not be change, invalidating the Government's own argument.

Certainly it would be hard to find any desire for a Federal takeover in Western Australia, where 90 per cent of companies registered with the State Corporate Affairs Commission (CAC) do not trade interstate and where $10m on company registration accounts is contributed to State revenue. Yet we have a Federal Labor Government which is trying to impose its whims and wishes on a State that does not want a bar of it.

The Western Australian Corporate Affairs Commission has built up a most valuable local expertise in a State where oil and mining are of such significance. It has provided the essential service of prompt rulings and decisions, backed by local knowledge, in a very personal manner. Any moves towards a centralised bureaucracy that cannot provide equality of service to a smaller and remote State, imposing additional costs and a basic instability are, in my opinion, to be deplored. The statement of the Acting Commissioner of the Western Australian CAC quoted in the dissenting report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation is an eloquent testimony as to the efficiency of the cooperative scheme. This Government cannot refute the statement of Mr O'Connor that such major changes as the growth of the futures industry and the greater internationalisation of business have been successfully accommodated under the present system.

This Government in its arrogance-there is no other word for it than `arrogance'-chooses to ignore the argument of the Law Institute of Victoria that true uniformity of companies and securities law can be maintained only through a cooperative scheme because of the real legal doubts and problems occasioned by unilateral Commonwealth action. Without the continued cooperation of the States the legal certainty that now exists in companies and securities-and, I might add, that is so essential to business life-will simply disappear. How any government in its right mind, with sane thinking people who do not have an ulterior motive, could possibly propose that absolutely bewilders me. This brings into focus the greatest weakness of the Hon. Lionel Bowen's corporate law takeover-its dubious legality. We heard Senator Hill only this evening talk about that dubious legality. The Federal Government has based its right to legislate on a legal opinion by Sir Maurice Byers. We heard Senator Tate interject earlier tonight that he was a most efficient and effective member of the legal profession. I grant that; I grant that he has a distinguished legal record-I would be silly if I did not-but he is not the repository of all legal wisdom, and the Government would be even more silly to believe that he was. Moreover, he is a committed centralist who, in the wake of the rejection of the referenda last September, demanded that the Federal Government keep trying to impose centralist solutions to our economic difficulties. That is simply not the answer, yet this is the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers on which so much weight has been placed.

However, last August the Law Council of Australia expressed real doubt as to whether the Commonwealth had the power to cover all classes of corporation that need to come within an effective regulatory system. According to section 51 (xx) of the Constitution, as the relevant Commonwealth power is confined to foreign corporations, and trading or financial corporations fall within the limits of the Commonwealth, some corporations will inevitably fall outside this definition. There will be a need for complementary State legislation, which will not be easy to achieve after the Federal Government has acted in this unilateral and irresponsible manner, and uniformity will be all but impossible to achieve. There could be endless litigation as to whether particular corporations were covered by Federal or State legislation, quite apart from the general likelihood of a High Court challenge to the validity of this Bill. Whatever the final outcome of such a challenge, business would be in for a very long period of uncertainty. I do not believe that that is in the best interests of this country or in the best interests of the States. It is a measure of the shallowness of this Government that its 1,200 pages of legislation and its 280 amendments railroaded through the House of Representatives last year after a few hours' notice to the Opposition-which I might add was tried again today-do not provide for effective transitional arrangements. Business will be left to pay the bill and that is just unacceptable. I am left wondering why the Government continues to railroad these packages through and tries to bluff the Opposition at every turn, particularly when the legislation is of such importance to this country.

The Law Council has warned this Government that it would be irresponsible to legislate without amending the Constitution. This Government dares not proceed to such an amendment when the Australian people have shown exactly what they think of centralist constitutional vandalism. However, legal uncertainty is but one disastrous effect of this Bill. I have already touched upon the danger of centralising companies and securities regulations under one source of political power. That course of action cannot be trusted.

On a more mundane but equally important level the new Australian Securities Commission (ASC) would suffer the defects of an essentially bureaucratic organisation controlled by the Attorney-General's Department. Business would encounter a decision-making body slow to react because of its removal from the realities of the marketplace, unlike the present National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) and the State CACs. The ASC will be staffed under the Public Service Act, which I suppose could be described as a formula for atrophy. There are solid grounds for believing that despite its centralised authority the ASC will be a far less effective corporate watchdog than the present NCSC.

One of the most dishonest actions of this Labor Government throughout this whole exercise is the claim that the NCSC is not up to the job, having forced it to operate, I might add, on a shoestring budget of $6m, with the effect that talented staff continually and rapidly disappeared into the private sector. The fact that its staff numbers are now to be increased is, I hope, at least a recognition of previous neglect. Nevertheless, the NCSC has played a most vigorous role to the limits of its resources in exposing the antics of corporate spivs who may just happen to be good mates of some Labor politicians. No wonder powerful sections of the Labor Party resent Mr Bosch's use of the media and would love to see him replaced by a faceless bureaucrat. We should take very seriously the claim of Mr Bosch on 2 February this year that `this is a Bill for a weaker watchdog' and that `the present Commission is regarded as too powerful and a positive attempt has been made in this Bill to convert a powerful and independent watchdog into a lap dog of the Attorney-General's Department'. Is it any wonder that the Government does not want to see Mr Bosch there when he is saying things of that nature? Confidence among investors will not be strengthened by the loss of expertise that will occur through the replacement of the NCSC and the downgrading of State CACs. Any responsible government would simply increase the resources of the NCSC to enable it to recruit able professional staff to oversee Australian corporate activity. More realistic fees, as highlighted in the minority report of the Select Committee, would provide greater financial resources through the user pays principle.

In opposing this Bill, I do not suggest that it is in any way the view of the Opposition that all aspects of the present cooperative regulatory system are perfect. Many reforms may be desirable-I emphasise the word `may'-and changes will always need to be made to adapt to different realities, but do we need to be a bull at a gate and make changes for change's sake as opposed to making changes for necessity? I should probably say: should we be making changes for the Attorney-General's sake and the sake of the ideology of the Labor Party in terms of going to an election within the foreseeable future, or making a change for necessity? What is clear, however, is that these reforms can be made through the present cooperative mechanism, whereby at the end of the day complete national uniformity and certainty can be guaranteed.

One area that requires the most careful examination and change is crown immunity. That is now so open to abuse as statutory bodies, such as the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission, intervene in the corporate sector to an unhealthy degree. Private business has been given an undesirable incentive to involve crown instrumentalities in their dealings to avoid proper regulatory scrutiny. It would be too much to expect this Labor Government to turn its energies to genuine reform in place of expensive legislative centralism.

This Bill is not about reform or better administration but about the centralisation of political power. It simply will not benefit the great majority of Australian businesses and in time will add greatly to their costs. I support wholeheartedly the Opposition amendment, which proposes:

Leave out all words after `That', insert `the existing co-operative scheme has served Australia well and should be retained with appropriate amendments, to enhance the scheme in the light of experience since its inception and to update and strengthen its national regulatory role'.
This Bill ought to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to some of the debate tonight and particularly to Senator Knowles, it is quite apparent that there is a major gulf between the Government side of the Parliament and the Opposition side. The gulf is not ideological; nor is it political. It is that some people in this Parliament are very much tuned in to the needs of Australia both now and in the future and some on the other side, if not most, have absolutely no idea.
—That is not you.

—I sat here listening to Senator Knowles and I did not interrupt. I expect that in that spirit she will do the same. What we are presented with today is a plan that has been discussed not only in the last few months but in the last few years. It is a plan for an adequate response by government in Australia to the needs of corporate regulation in this country. It is a plan that was mooted initially a number of years ago. It is a plan which conceptually was agreed to by a unanimous report of the Senate in 1987. Members of all parties in the Senate came together and agreed that conceptually the best way to approach the whole system of corporate regulation in this country was to take a national approach to it. That is precisely what this Government is doing with this legislation now.

SPEECH.PARA: Any reflection on the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on a personal level or on a political level is a very shallow one; it is a very inadequate one; it is a poor one. Those who make such a suggestion know it to be so. They know that what drives the person behind this legislation is the fact that we in Australia and in particular the Attorney-General recognise that for us to be able to compete now and in the future we must approach this particular regulatory problem on a national level.

The old scheme has not worked. It is undisputed that it has not worked. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs unanimously agreed that it did not work. People in the corporate sector and in the regulatory sector all agree that the old scheme did not work. Once again on this side of the Parliament a Minister has been prepared to seize upon the issue, to tackle it and to give the Australian community a response that we require. We are no longer dealing with the horse and buggy days of corporate regulation. We are not dealing with six minor economies spread across this country. We are dealing with the demands of national economic planning. That, together with the demands of international competitiveness, means that what we should have in this country is a system of regulation which can respond very quickly and adequately to those demands. What we have at the moment does not do that at all.

In the deliberations of the Senate Committee in 1987 it became abundantly clear that the existing system of the cooperative scheme was inefficient in terms of meeting the demands of the modern economy in an international financial framework. As I said, the Senate Committee unanimously concluded that the cooperative scheme had outlived its usefulness and that the Commonwealth should assume total responsibility in this area. There were some fundamental defects. We on that Committee recognised that they were there. We on that Committee recognised that the current scheme had outgrown its present phase. We also recognised that some of the problems were insoluble.

For the Opposition to come before us today with a proposal that says that we need to improve the current cooperative scheme by, for instance, giving the Commonwealth a weighted vote just shows how out of touch the Opposition is. It just does not see that the inherent flaws in the system cannot be met with this sort of proposal. Even the person who gave birth to this proposal, the former chairperson of the Ministerial Council, recognised that such a proposal was dead.

All this proposal does-I am sorry to say that it reflects very badly on the shadow spokesman in this place, Senator Hill-is underscore the fact that those on the other side are totally irrelevant to the mainstream economic and regulatory debate in this country. The problem is not faced on the Government side by an ideological or political response as has been suggested by other speakers. It has been recognised across the board, both in business and in politics, that the current scheme is inadequate. Even Mr Tony Hartnell, a former Acting Chairman of the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission who was appointed by the Greiner Government to oversee the operation of that Commission, has called for the abolition of the cooperative scheme and the introduction of Commonwealth legislation. Even Mr Bosch, who is now revered by those on the other side, in his submission to the previous Senate Committee which I chaired, recognised that there were problems in the current scheme that were insurmountable.

One of the major problems put to the Committee and one of the major problems that no enhancement of the cooperative scheme can address is the administrative inefficiency and inconsistencies between States in Australia. We can have one law but we can never guarantee that administratively it will be applied in the same way. That evidence came before us time and time again. It is that sort of evidence that those on the other side insist on ignoring when approaching this particular resolution to the problem.

We have a national economy. We have national markets. We have a security market which no longer operates as a separate State based market. Individual stock exchanges have now formed into one Australian stock exchange. Company operations no longer end at State borders. Yet all these particular parts of the corporate sector are being asked to comply with laws that are being differently administered in each State. What does this do? It imposes unnecessary burdens on business. In my area of consumer affairs alone I quite often get calls from people in the corporate sector who say, `Look, we're one national economy but we've got to comply with six different approaches. Can't the Federal Government do something about it?'. Using this approach we are actually doing something about it. I do not dwell on the point that no longer do we have a national market but rather a market with international dimensions. Those sorts of dimensions place greater needs on particularly the corporate sector, the securities market and finance sector. We need to have a system which is much more responsive. This is precisely what the Government is doing.

Speakers on the other side have mentioned the problem of crime and said that by introducing this system we would be somehow running away from our obligations in terms of pursuing corporate crime in Australia. There are some major authorities in corporate crime in this country. Even as recently as 1986 those authorities concluded that the cooperative scheme was inadequate to deal with the investigation of corporate crime. They call for a national scheme. They were no lesser authorities than Dr John Braithwaite and Dr Peter Grabowsky in their book entitled Of Matters Gentle: Enforcement Strategies of Australian Business Regulatory Agencies. We have to contend with corporate crime not only domestically but also on an international level. Anyone who has actually dealt with other countries in this particular area is confronted continually with a problem and poses the question: `Why can't you run your corporate system on a Federal level?'. How can authorities be expected to deal with six, if not eight, different and differing jurisdictions in Australia when they recognise that our market is very much a national one, if not an international one?

During the second reading debate, a few complaints were raised. We were told that we are persisting with this proposal in the face of opposition from the business community. It is a fallacy to say that; it is total ignorance to submit that that is the case. Once again, that ignorance reflects very much on the point of view and the understanding of the real issues facing Australia of members opposite.

I will list some key business groups who support the proposal. The Business Council of Australia does so, but in latter days, the Liberal Party has said that it is too close to the Government. We have been told that only big business supports the proposal. However, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, COSBOA, supports it. The Institute of Chartered Accountants supports it, as do the Australian Society of Accountants, the Company Directors Association of Australia, the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, and others. More recently, the Australian Merchant Bankers Association has called for prompt action to establish the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). I say `more recently' because it did not support it in the past. It has seen the light. All those organisations reflect one particular point that needs to be stressed time and again. Members opposite are locked in the politics of the 1960s and no matter what changes have happened in the Liberal Party that sort of locking in to days of old has not changed, and will not change.

We were told that we have not consulted widely. As I mentioned earlier, 1987 was the time of the first major consultative process, when a committee of the Parliament discussed the concept of national legislation. We heard a host of submissions. Such was the overwhelming weight of those submissions that honourable senators on all sides of the Parliament agreed to a national approach at that time. A small number of vocal groups in the smaller States now oppose any form of national legislation. They have been indulging in a campaign of deliberate misinformation, particularly in States such as Queensland and Western Australia. These groups are out to do nothing more than protect local vested interests at the expense of the national interest. Once again, as with every other micro-economic reform issue facing this country, the Opposition bows down to them. It bows down to them all the time, only to be kicked in the guts every time it does so because business time and again has supported it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who prepared that nonsense for you?

—Senator Hill is a great example of this. He was a member of that parliamentary committee in 1987. He quite gladly and openly welcomed the concept of national legislation, but somehow he changes his mind today. Senator Hill should know more than anyone else that conceptually, in terms of the problems this country faces, we are going the right way. No smirk on his face will convince me that he agrees with that.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving aside that Senate Committee, the Attorney-General has consistently and continually consulted with industry and the community in order to accommodate the legitimate concerns of the community. As I said, big business and small business alike support this proposal. State governments and their advisers have had access to these drafts for quite some time. They have been circulated for almost 18 months, if not two years. They were laid on the table of the House. Two parliamentary committees received submissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two pages of amendments.

—Senator Hill is dead right when he raises the question of two pages of amendments. It is a great testament to the fact that the Attorney-General has embarked upon a meaningful, consultative process. Two pages of amendments have arisen from the Joint Parliamentary Committee deliberations and report. Even today, in discussions with Senator Hill and the Australian Democrats, the Government showed that it is still prepared to accept more amendments. We are not ideologically fixed. We are not firmly entrenched in a position. We are concerned about achieving a result that is for the good of Australia.
—Oh, come on!

—The only constructive thing Senator Hill has done today is get rid of his leader. I am not so sure that will be for the good of Australia. While we are on the subject, Senator Hill raised the subject of constitutional doubt.
—There is a great deal of constitutional doubt.
—Senator Hill is one of those senators who only two years ago were swayed by an eminent legal opinion before the previous Senate Committee-the one I chaired and of which he was deputy chairman--
—And a good deputy chairman.

—He was, too. He was swayed by the legal opinion which was to the effect that the Federal Government had absolutely no doubt on the constitutional point. Not only did we get that advice from Sir Maurice Byers, a most eminent constitutional lawyer, we also got advice from a previous coalition government Minister, Solicitor-General, and Attorney-General from the party of Senator Hill and Senator Puplick, Mr Robert Ellicott. There is no doubt about the constitutional validity of this legislation. Even State law officers when raising problems with it do not go to the heart of the constitutional problem. They go to the peripheral issues. They will go through their charade, but it should also be noted on the record that the Attorney-General has bent over backwards in terms of accommodating the States' legitimate claims. If State Attorneys-General, including some of the Labor ones, are not prepared to play ball and are more prepared to play local State pedantic politics than to care about the national good, we will not bow down to those sorts of sectional interests.
—Watch it, Nick. It could be the same faction.

—I am sure the Government that Senator Hill would ever be part of would be. I return to Senator Hill's point. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in 1987 saw that there was absolutely no doubt about the constitutional validity of this legislation. Senator Hill knows it and he agrees to it. It is good to see Senator Macklin coming into this place. I place on the record that in terms of someone with political perspicacity and foresight, next to the Attorney-General, Senator Macklin is the one person who has recognised that this legislation is necessary and imperative for Australian business to meet the needs and demands of the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Knowles is a bit of a small player in this game, but she talked independence from political interference. It is a pity that other honourable senators mentioned that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you, geniuses? You should be the last one to talk about small contributions.
—Order! That is enough.
—Well, you pull him up when he says Senator Knowles is a bit player.
—Order!

—The allegation of political interference has been made. If Senator Puplick had any weight in his Party, he would not be floating around in the wind with the direction of his environmental policy, as he has been. Let us return to the basic issue. In terms of independence from political interference, the claim has been made that the responsible Minister will be able to give the ASC general directions about the policies it should pursue or the priorities it should follow. That has been put forward as a major point, but it is not a major point; it is in the legislation. We are saying that the Minister will have no power to give specific directions about a particular case. In that respect, the ASC should be free from political interference in performing its functions.

SPEECH.PARA: We are also saying that those policy directions will have to be in writing; they will have to be gazetted; and they will have to be tabled in Parliament. We are not running away from the fact that we believe in parliamentary scrutiny. This legislation makes the whole corporate regulatory system directly accountable to parliamentary scrutiny. In the past, those on Senator Hill's side of the Parliament and those on our side have been frustrated continually by the fact that problems have arisen-problems that we could never meet with any great degree of responsiveness and flexibility because we have always been confronted with a compact which has been agreed to by State and Federal Attorneys.

This Parliament's role, like that of every other Parliament, has been recognised as being that of a rubber stamp. With this legislation, we are making the whole system directly accountable to the Parliament. Any degree of political interference will be directly accountable to the Parliament. The ASC chairperson, for instance, will have the opportunity to discuss with the Minister the need for direction and the Minister will be accountable to the Parliament for any directions that he or she gives.

The other basic part of this point that should be recognised here is that the proposal has emanated from the Joint Parliamentary Committee's recommendations, but we will have a parliamentary committee oversighting the implementation of the legislation and the running of it. That is also a great advance, something which does not take place at the moment, something which could not be met in terms of the existing corporate scheme. The other claim that has been made-and I think that I should dwell on this in order once again to highlight the lack of understanding both of the need and of the proposal put forward by the Government-is that the Australian Securities Commission Bill provides only for the employment of staff subject to Public Service pay limits and that, as a consequence, we will be losing staff from the structure, from the ASC and from the pre-existing National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). That claim has been made in a press statement by Senator Alston. It is a statement that has been put out irresponsibly everywhere. Not only will the ASC, like the NCSC, be able to appoint staff on Public Service terms and conditions; not only will it be able to engage consultants on terms and conditions, as the ASC determines under clause 129 of the Bill, but in addition the ASC will have significant new capacity-and I hope that Senator Hill will listen to this because it is for his education as much as for anyone else's-to employ, under contract, such staff as it thinks necessary. This power will enable the ASC to determine the terms and conditions of the employment of those persons subject to the Minister's overall agreement. So it will give the ASC greater capacity to employ high level staff from the marketplace and with knowledge of the marketplace.

I do not need to say much more other than that once again we have had today an instance in which, when we talk about macro-economic reform, when we talk about cost to industry and when we talk about cost to the economy, this Government recognises the need to streamline the processes. This Government recognises the need for more flexible and responsible systems. Once again, however, the Opposition is locked into its small sectoral interests and resisting any degree of change-despite the fact that in the past it has agreed with the concept. It is regrettable that speaker after speaker on the other side, short of rational argument, has dwelt on the role of the Attorney-General in this process. The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has been in this Parliament much longer than most of those honourable senators opposite-in some cases, since before they were born. They have made allegations about his personal motivations and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has had a bad couple of years. How did the referenda go?

—When Senator Hill is rolled at the next election, and when the economy continues on its course, there is one thing the people will remember-that there was one person in this country who in 1989 was prepared to grasp the nettle on this issue and to give Australia a corporate regulatory system allowing it to operate efficiently and fairly in 1989 and into the future.
